src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/reporting-waste-inefficiency-should-be-easy-and-safe
 
 
 Reporting Waste &amp; Inefficiency should be Easy and Safe
 
 Recovery.gov should provide an easy and safe way for people who want to report waste, fraud &amp; abuse (or just plain inefficiency) with respect to Recovery spending. 
 As President Obama recently stated , the people who are closest to the work are the ones most likely to see the waste and inefficiency in that work. 
 And, with respect to Recovery spending, that means employees of government (federal, state, &amp; local), as well as employees of contractors to government . 
 However , those employees will not report waste or inefficiency if (1) they are unaware or confused about how to report it, or if (2) there is a risk that they will lose their job for making the report. 
 Yes, the traditional "whistleblower protections" for federal employees are now also extended to contractor employees under the the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 ("ARRA"). But those "protections" are so weak that only the most naive of federal employees actually believe that they work. (The wise ones have seen what really happens to the "whistleblowers".) 
 However, now there is technology that Recovery.gov can use that allows a person to report waste or inefficiency AND, at the same time, gives them sufficient confidence that they will not be "found out" by their supervisors. 
 I'm not talking about the "old" system offered by the govt. IGs or the GAO's Fraudnet, who expect the employee to trust their career to a complete stranger. I'm talking about outside-the-government vendors whose technology (and reputation) offer employees the level of control and confidentiality needed before they will "blow the whistle" on their organization. 
 I don't have a list of these vendors (nor do I work for any of them), but I know that some of them are on the GSA's list of pre-approved vendors (i.e., a federal agency could purchase their services very quickly). 
 The CEO of one of those vendors has a blog-posting about the <a class="external-link" href="http://tinyurl.com/dhxjfq">ARRA's legal requirements for a whistleblowing system </a>needed by public and private organization that receive Recovery funds. Recovery.gov should provide an easy-to-understand "FAQs" on that topic (with links) for the benefit of those employers and employees. 
 In fact, it would be a very powerful symbol if the Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board (RATB) itself adopted this better-than-legal system for people to report (confidentially or not) opportunities for improvement in the RATB's operations (including Recovery.gov) and not just limit it to a one-time, one-week window (like this platform). 
 
 Any auditor will tell you that the single biggest source for detecting waste, fraud &amp; abuse (in any organization) comes from "tips" and information provided by the employees who see it. 
 If we make it easy and and safe for employees to make those reports, then more of them will do so which, in turn, will be the single biggest deterrent to waste, fraud and abuse (and, yes, just plain inefficiency) in the use of Recovery funds. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/evaluation-helps-us-spend-the-dollar-once
 
 
 Evaluation Helps Us Spend the Dollar Once
 
 Evaluation is a challenging task under any condition. It involves all kinds of methodologies, both quantitative and qualitative. 
 While it is essential and very important, it often scares people and local agencies to death, costs a small fortune and rarely leaves communities with the capacity to do it themselves. 
 Quantitative data is essential, but doesn't always leave much behind. Also, unless presented in an entertaining way or with a big punch, it might not stick in the public's mind. Collecting dry data can miss the real wins in a program or community. 
 Five Ideas: 
 Plan with Results in Mind . Beyond the grant or funding purpose, how else will the community define success. They may not be exactly the same. 
 Count Big and Little Wins . We want to account for unexpected wins, big and small. Results can fly under the scientific radar. Real and sustainable success relies on many variables, not just one or two. Make room for candid community evaluation. 
 Failure Analysis is a Vehicle for Success : Silicon Valley successes are built on a million failures. The same is true of really effective programs. Good evaluation is a tool for continuous improvement not a grading system upon which future funding depends. The evaluation paradigm needs to be updated. 
 Build Community Capacity 
 Everything we do should leave people better off, with more capacity, than before the federal money touched their lives. Ideally we will leave people with more tools and capacity so our investment can be sustained past funding. 
 Evaluation is a Story 
 
 Tell the public a story, involve the recipient of funding as a partner. People love stories, big or small. Turning results into a story will capture the public imagination. Past the data, people need to relate to the data. Stories do that. 
 I used this methodology in evaluating the Advancing Community Policing Grants for COPS/Justice. My partners were local law enforcement agencies. It worked well, was published, shared credit, and the fear factor went way down. This did not cost a lot of money. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The target audience for this idea is the general public and the recipients of funding. 
 The public wants to know what happened with the money. We are making an investment in the future of the United States. President Obama has promised transparency, accountability and results. 
 Our job is to find out and explain clearly, what happened with the public dollar. The pubic is a big partner, ideally this money will leave behind sustainable programs and help us get to a place where we spend the public dollar once. 
 How we tell this story matters a lot, should capture the public imagination, honor different learning styles, and create pride and excitement. 
 This is more likely to happen if the data is digestable and useful to the American public. Everyone remembers being told stories as a child, adults like it too. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/require-consistent-recordkeeping-practices-for-fund-recipients
 
 
 Require Consistent Recordkeeping Practices for Fund Recipients
 
 To require compliance with a program that demonstrates transparency, oversight and accountability by maintaining precise and authentic financial and administrative records for allocating and disbursing funds. 
 Provide a methodology for a standardized audit and oversight, and ensure that information is ready for future FOIA requests and examinations. 
 
 Adherence to Generally Accepted Recordkeeping Principles will result in standardization of documentation as it relates to the appropriation of the funds. 
 The audit function can be standardized across all entities that receive federal funds leading to clear and transparent interpretation of results. This will enable effective oversight and consistent reporting to the taxpayers of the United States. 
 Recipients should be advised to develop programs that adhere to the following Generally Accepted Recordkeeping Principles : 
 · Principle of Accountability 
 An organization shall assign a senior executive who will oversee a recordkeeping program and delegate program responsibility to appropriate individuals, adopt policies and procedures to guide personnel, and ensure program auditability. 
 
 · Principle of Integrity 
 A recordkeeping program shall be constructed so the records and information generated or managed by or for the organization have a reasonable and suitable guarantee of authenticity and reliability. 
 
 · Principle of Protection 
 A recordkeeping program shall be constructed to ensure a reasonable level of protection to records and information that are private, confidential, privileged, secret, or essential to business continuity. 
 
 · Principle of Compliance 
 The recordkeeping program shall be constructed to comply with applicable laws and other binding authorities, as well as the organization's policies. 
 
 · Principle of Availability 
 An organization shall maintain records in a manner that ensures timely, efficient, and accurate retrieval of needed information. 
 
 · Principle of Retention 
 An organization shall maintain its records and information for an appropriate time, taking into account legal, regulatory, fiscal, operational, and historical requirements. 
 
 · Principle of Disposition 
 An organization shall provide secure and appropriate disposition for records that are no longer required to be maintained by applicable laws and the organization's policies. 
 
 · Principle of Transparency 
 The processes and activities of an organization's recordkeeping program shall be documented in an understandable manner and be available to all personnel and appropriate interested parties.

 How To Engineer Site &amp; Data Structure - Basics
 
 Organize data such that it allows for drill down or drill in, starting at the Federal / National level, going to State and local levels.

 Pictures speak louder than columns of numbers, so the GUI should be very graphical in its presentation, liberal use of charts and graphs. You have a good start on this already . 
 The underlying structure can be composed of a SQL based database and HTML presentation pages. It doesn't need a ton of high tech solutions, this is a simple data gathering and reporting application. 
 
 Gathering data at the local and state level will be the rub. 
 
 Provide a web based input portal for this purpose and require each local or state receiving recovery funds to report, at least monthly, project progress. Every project should have a project manager at the local level, so this should not be a huge burden. 
 
 The portal will require security and some data input reasonability check, as well as some federal oversight, to ensure anomaly's are dealt with before release to the general public. 
 
 
 This idea needs more detailing, but Im hoping you have staff that have already thought this thru, so thanks for the chance to comment. 
 
 By the way, you will need to provide an area for citizens to comment on the web site, everyone loves to give their opinion, dont they? 
 
 Perhaps adding access points, via Facebook or twitter or linkedin or others will help evangelize the sites presence. 
 
 
 You cant just throw some tech at this and hope it fits. There needs to be some time spent on design of the data collection method, data warehousing tool, the visulization and site design / wire framing. It has to have some "stickyness" to it or citizens wont visit. 
 The given time frame ( 4/23 to 5/3) for comment is not enough time. The subject requires discussion and dedicated mind share, not just posting ideas and comments.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/six-data-centric-management-principles-for-recovery.org
 
 
 Six data-centric Management Principles for Recovery.org 
 
 Achieving full
transparency and accountability for Recovery act stimulus funds is a delicate
data driven effort that requires careful deliberate implementation. To accomplish the goals of this initiative--to
collect and present data associated with stimulus funding in order to make it
easy and useful for anyone to track the funds and impact of recovery, all in a
transparent and collaborative fashion--requires the right technology, processes,
and approach to ensure the successful data sharing and collaborative partnership between public and private
sector necessary for national economic recovery. 
 
 The following six
data-centric principles establish a foundation of transparency and
collaboration necessary to forge a private/public sector partnership that
achieves the goals of the historic Economic Recovery Act. 
 In short, the solution for
recovery.gov requires that Recovery Data be: 
 1. Easily Collectible. Given the
breadth of purposes for stimulus funds and the number of government agencies,
partners, vendors, organizations and individuals involved, to ensure successful rapid delivery of a data
management solution, recovery.gov must implement a solution that allows
for the automated collection, reporting, and organization of data from the
widest range sources (e.g., as systems, databases, mainframes, flat files),
interfaces (e.g., web-services, EDI) and
formats (Excel, XML) possible without costly custom coding or integration. Additionally, cloud hosted services could provide
an effective scalable cost competitive approach for handling source data files
coming from hundreds or even thousands of organizations for loading into
persistent storage areas such as Operational Data Stores, Enterprise Data
Warehouses, or Data Marts or staging areas. 
In short, given today's technology, connectivity and handling of data in
various existing data sources and formats should not be an impediment for
organizations providing data to recovery.gov. 
 2. High Quality. As learned by
hundreds of companies and organizations over the last decade, accessibility of data
is not enough. Data must be consistent,
complete, and clean (error free) to be useful. 
While practically "perfect data" does not exist, the Recovery
Team can ensure Recovery Data remains meaningful through development of a data
governance program that establishes standards and accountability for
maintaining effective data quality for submitted data, and implementation
supporting automated tools and processes that will help identify and resolve
data quality issues in collaboration with data providers and stakeholders on an
ongoing basis. 
 3. Presentation
Agnostic. Integration costs and associated code
maintenance are rapidly becoming one of the most expensive aspects of data
system maintenance. To ensure the
recovery.gov solution remains low maintenance and low cost, the Recovery Team
needs a solution that makes Recovery Data easy to access, analyze and use. Consistent with industry best practices,
data should be separated (e.g. via a data warehouse or data marts) and managed
independent of presentation and application logic. This separation when coupled with standard
integration interfaces should allow Recovery Data to be accessed and used by a
wide range of tools, systems and technologies. 
For example, the solution could support presentation of canned reports
via the recovery.org site, provide standard web search interfaces, integrate
with business intelligence tools for reports and trend analysis, and
interoperate with data mining tools to support robust monitoring by regulators
and law enforcement, to name a few. 
 4. Web Accessible /
Mashable. The Recovery Team can provide significant
capabilities at minimal cost by harnessing the power of the private
sector. As proven by recent Internet
developments, Web 2.0 sites have already proven the significant advantages of open
access to data sources. By providing
data feeds that make Recovery information accessible and retrievable by
external web-services, the Recovery team can harness the creative power of the
private sector by allowing developers to create a host of value-added
applications. Just as internet site
zillow.com has created a valuable service by combining existing public records,
Real Estate information, and Microsoft map data, enterprising individuals and
organizations in both the public and private sector will be able to harness
recovery data to create applications that track the usage of government funds
and assess the impact of recovery efforts, thereby providing tremendous value
at minimal cost to the Recovery Team. 
 5. Highly Reliable,
Always Available. Few things pose a greater risk to the appearance and
promise of transparency than downtime or other technical issues that prevent
interested parties from consistently and reliably accessing Recovery Data. While superficially, system outages, even for
short periods, may seem innocuous, in the global court of public opinion, such
outages can lead to a perceived lack of openness, or even incompetence. To prevent such misperceptions, and ensure
consistent access to government data, the Recovery Team must provide a highly
available environment proven capable of scaling to provide uninterrupted
support for all of recovery.gov's data collection and dissemination
efforts. Additionally, for web applications
to work, developers creating mashable sites will require similar consistent
always-on real-time access to Recovery Data. 
 6. Verifiable and
Auditable. Beyond effective management and accessibility of
data, ensuring that economic recovery funds are appropriately spent requires
that data consumers (such as regulators, the media, and law enforcement) be
able to determine where the data originated, who provided it, and when it was
received. By implementing metadata
management tools that leverage existing metadata from systems submitting data,
the recovery team can simplify data tracking by automating much of this
typically onerous but highly critical regulatory process. 
 About Informatica 
 Informatica is a leading
provider of enterprise data integration software and services. With
Informatica, organizations can gain
greater business value by integrating all their information assets from
across
the enterprise. Used by hundreds of successful very large
organizations worldwide, Informatica's data integration platform
combines industry leading tools with the unmatched ease of use needed
to rapidly address the full range of organizations' data integration
challenges.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/leverage-existing-database
 
 
 Leverage existing Database
 
 It would be nice to use a database like FRED as the St. Louis Federal Reserve to collect relevant metrics with which to model the effectiveness of the stimulus package. Many of us already use this database for various econometric models and find it to be reasonably well maintained. Unfortunately, it is often lacking the regional, temporal or industry specific granularity that we would like to have, but it is a good starting point and provides tools one can use to import the relevant time series into sophisticated statistical packages for time series analysis, intervention analysis, causality testing, etc. Every effort should be made to collect data at the highest possible frequency. Weekly would be ideal, but monthly observations would be adequate and make seasonal adjustment easier. 
 
 We should leverage existing technology and make the data available to the widest possible audience. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/adopt-effective-it-complexity-management
 
 
 Adopt Effective IT Complexity Management
 
 
 All Federal IT projects should adopt a formal mechanism for managing the complexity of new IT projects. 
 
 66% of all Federal IT dollars are invested in high risk projects, that is, projects that are likely to fail. This number has been steadily increasing. It was 30% in 2007, 43% in 2008. At the current rate of increase, by the year 2010 this number will be close to 100% 
 
 Not only is IT failure a huge cost to the Federal budget ($47 billion, in 2009), but there is an even larger cost to the US economy as a whole. For every dollar in direct cost, there is at least another five dollars in indirect costs. The actual costs to the US economy are therefore in the neighborhood of $300 billion dollars per year. 
 
 The reason that so many Federal IT projects are at high risk is that there is no effective IT complexity management strategy. The complexity of the systems being build is increasing and the tools for project management have not kept pace. 
 
 Complexity is exponentially related to functionality. That means that as the functionality of an IT system increases, its complexity increases much faster. And both system cost and system risk go up with complexity, so small additions of functionality can increase the risk of failure dramatically especially as the system approaches the breaking point, as most Federal IT systems have. 
 
 The answer to this is a Federally mandated program to train IT managers in understanding how complexity impacts IT systems and developing effective processes for managing and mitigating IT complexity. Not only would such a program greatly reduce the failure risk of Federal IT systems, it would also reduce their cost. 
 
 In general, the answer to IT complexity is found in partitioning IT systems based on synergies between functionality. Applying this concept to a large IT system can reduce the overall complexity, cost, and risk of system failure by at least 75%. If this approach is applied across the entire spectrum of Federal IT, we can expect to reduce the cost of Federal IT from today's $71 billion per year to around $35 billion per year. 
 
 Not only will we reduce the cost, but we will see a dramatic improvement in the number of systems that are actually delivered. We will also see an marked improvement in the quality of those systems. 
 
 This program is a win-win strategy. We save money at the same time as we improve government. 
 
 For more information on the nature of complexity in Federal IT systems, see the editorial in the Perspectives of the International Association of Software Architects available at http://www.objectwatch.com/white_papers.htm#EditorialIASA

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/how-to-improve-the-value-of-recovery-gov-data-1
 
 
 How to Improve the Value of Recovery.gov Data
 
 The Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board should work with the Federal Chief Financial Officer's (CFO) Council and industry to develop guidance for agencies in securing Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) financial management platforms to manage the financial data submitted to Recovery.gov. This guidance should encourage agencies to purchase Information Technology (IT) solutions that easily integrate with existing systems, and enable agencies to view financial data at the macro- and micro-levels (e.g., project code, organization, by vendor, etc.). In addition, this guidance should recommend that these solutions are scalable and facilitate agency use of financial management data for improved performance management, project management, and capital planning. 
 
 Providing transparency and accountability into the use of American Reinvestment and Recovery Act (ARRA) funds is essential. Just as important, however, is making sure that agencies reap the benefits of this data to improve planning and financial management. Without the capability to view and analyze this data, reporting to Recovery.gov runs the risk of becoming simply another government data call. Unfortunately, many agencies rely on a complex system of Excel spreadsheets and/or homegrown IT systems to manage their financial data. The result is that these agencies are unable to fully analyze ARRA - and other agency data - over the long-term to make better business decisions that link program, organization, and agency investments with performance metrics and mission success. With guidance from the Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board, the CFO Council, and industry, agencies will see purchasing financial management IT solutions as an Administration priority and act on it, ultimately improving the value of Recovery.gov data and the effectiveness of government. 
 
 Christen Bergerud 
 Managing Director, Sales and Services 
 EcoSys (<a href="http://www.ecosysmgmt.com">www.ecosysmgmt.com</a>)

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/low-cost-subscription-application-tracks-stimulus-projects
 
 
 Low Cost Subscription Application tracks Stimulus Projects
 
 
 
 ActiveStrategy StimulusScorecard(tm) -
available on the GSA schedule for the federal government - is a low-cost,
turn-key web-based service designed to allow recipients and subrecipients of
funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA or Recovery
Act) to effectively and proactively monitor and manage their projects and
programs. 
 
ActiveStrategy StimulusScorecard collects the project information required by
the ARRA and makes real-time data available so governments can identify the
preemptive action needed to prevent delays, waste, fraud, and abuse that could
undermine program performance and public confidence. Simply put, it is a
service that allows governments to monitor, manage, review, and report on all
stimulus programs and projects from one location. 
 
 
 <a class="external-link" href="http://forms.activestrategy.com/go/activestrategy/nationaldialogue_stimulus_webinar">View a demo of the system during the
second half of this recording.</a> 
 
 StimulusScorecard provides a secure, low-cost system that requires
virtually no IT support and can be online and ready to go in days. The package
includes ActiveStrategy Enterprise online scorecard software, documentation,
training, best practices measurement templates for the ARRA, telephone support,
help selecting key measures and objectives to get your system usable right
away, and ongoing analysis of OMB guidance. Coaching on how to use the system
to conduct reviews of stimulus-funded projects and ARRA strategy is included as
well. There is no software to buy or install - governments and agencies pay for
the system only for as long as it is needed as part of the management and
administrative costs of their stimulus projects. 
 
 
 
 ActiveStrategy StimulusScorecard allows
federal agency, state, city, and local officials, as well as other Recovery Act
recipients, to monitor and manage: 
 How efficiently and effectively the
 dollars are being spent in real time (i.e. are the programs on-time,
 on-budget, and on-quality from their original plan) How much impact there is on economic
 recovery (i.e. what long-term benefits are being realized in job creation
 productivity, energy efficiency, etc.) Who is responsible for projects and
 what updates are they providing on performance How many projects and how many
 dollars have been awarded, spent, obligated or are pending 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/create-the-center-for-continuous-corporate-transparency-market-risk-mgt
 
 
 Create the Center for Continuous Corporate Transparency &amp; Market Risk Mgt.
 
 
 
 The creation of an organization that would institute and
oversee the implementation of a standard corporate instrument and process for
regulatory, financial, and market compliance and reporting. This entity will create
a measurement infrastructure for all corporations to comprehensively manage change
and transactional risks associated with the US financial markets and their
associated companies. This SEC organization's
focus will be to aggregate (monitor); audit, regulatory, policy and risk controls
(measure); so that the SEC and their Self Regulated Organizations (SRO's);
working under the SEC can focus on managing what matters ( risk ; transactional,
portfolio, portfolio groups, corporate, industry, market). The overriding focus,
mission, and methodology is M 4 ( M onitor
(capture), M easure
(control/test(s)), so one can M anage
what M atters (Risk) . This center for Continuous Corporate
Transparency and Market Risk Management to actually make market risk manageable
will need to do the following five (5) items: 
 1. Create
a detailed definition of "What" will be the future state for automated market
controls management. 
 2. Extend
the work just completed on what when wrong in the financial institutions, the
rating organizations, the SRO's and with the auditors (i.e. defining current
state) 
 3. Develop
a Solution roadmap to go from current state to future state, 
 4. Development
of a working prototype to: 
 a. Create
a solution framework for continuous 100% transaction monitoring supporting the
overlapping COSO and CobiT compliance frameworks. 
 b. 
Automate the visibility, and as such the management
of currently invisible processes that have policies, regulations and risks. 
 c. 
A comprehensive Corporate Risk Transparency and
Controls solution will require technology that provides for centralized
Regulations/Policy/Controls/Tests Knowledge Base and Analysis/Decision Engine
focused on; A) Controls that define "What" is being measured, "Where" the data
is being gathered, "How" it is measured, "When" is it measured and "Who"
manages the results of the measurements, and B) the association of a control to
corporate policies and governmental regulations, using a rules based
transaction auditing and change approval system 
 d. 
Defining a standard "Unit of Work" process
definition methodology and associated Control/Test Knowledge entry 
 e. 
Visual BPM like process definition/modeling
integrated with the Analysis/Decision Engine 
 f. 
Infrastructure that monitors business applications
and the IT infrastructure supporting those applications 
 g. 
An end user self service Business Request Portal
(System) 
 h. 
Automated Transaction Audit documentation of the
analysis of business &amp; IT transactions with defined "Risks" stored securely
in an EDMS 
 i. 
Ability to document access to the Audited
Transaction EDMS (who, what, when, how long, how often etc.) 
 This high-impact solution provides benefit and extraordinary
value to every stakeholder; the American marketplace &amp; corporate America,
the governmental regulatory and compliance organizations &amp; committees,
corporate executives, employees, and investors. 
Once fully functional it will: 
 increase the quality of corporate reporting transform the compliance process from being a burden to
 being an event reduce the time and expense associated with any and all
 compliance requirements eliminate the invisibility of any/all corporate activities
 and non-systemic events, creating visibility, track and traceable, and
 manageability restore confidence in the management and execution of
 businesses in America. 
 
 
 
 
 By way of specific
example, it has been proven that widespread audit and policy violations have
been identified and disclosed involving incorrect audit certifications of
compliance with IT security policies by outside auditors, internal audit and IT
organizations. These violations are
profound because they allow funds, as well as financial and other records, to
be hidden, removed, altered or stolen. 
This is alarming because such violations seriously compromise the
integrity and reliability of the entire financial reporting system. 
 
 Similar
fundamental, systemic and potentially catastrophic violations are evident in a
broad range of financial policy in all parts of the financial system, not merely
in IT security. Such violations are not
being detected or reported because of current manual off-line audit practices
designed by the very audit organizations which administer them. Those procedures allow unreliable information
about asset positions and infrastructure about companies because of inadequate
verification and lack of automation of properly designed controls. 
 
 Audit practice
under current SEC policies establishes a foundation for corporate executives to
claim plausible deniability of violations because they obtained signed audit
reviews for audits. However, as noted,
those audits miss defects with potentially enormous consequences which are not
monitored or disclosed, and which are not visible under present practice. Corporations are not willing to acknowledge
the violations and auditors are unwilling to admit or identify any deficiency
in past audits they have performed. 
There is no incentive by auditors or corporations to change. 
 
 Only the SEC can
drive change. To do so, the SEC needs to
recognize and implement a change in current practice by implementing definitive
regulations and funding prototype controls and automated systems. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/governmentwide-financial-management-structures
 
 
 Governmentwide Financial Management Structures
 
 Build upon the existing Federal Financial Management system structures and infrastructures. 
 
 ARRA is only one of three legislative acts that require accountability and transparency in government. The Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006 (FFATA) requires "all" Federal Awards, i.e., expenditures be reported in a website that the public can access. Today that website is USASpending.gov. In addition, the legislation identifies specific criteria for data elements that are required to be reported. Section 1526(c)(7) of ARRA requires ARRA to include the data elements required to comply with FFATA plus also allowing aggregate reporting on awards below $25,000. Similarly, the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act, Trouble Asset Relief Program (EESA/TARP) Section 114, Market Transparency, requires the Secretary shall determine whether the public disclosure is adequate to provide to the public sufficient information as to the true financial position of the institutions. If such disclosure is not adequate for that purpose, the Secretary shall make recommendations for additional disclosure requirements to the relevant regulators. 
 
 Unless the Government consolidates the above legislative requirements into a single accountability and transparency imitative there will be a triplication of effort to produce the required financial information. In addition, Article I, Section 9, Clause 7 of the Constitution and 31 USC 3513(a) states: 
 Article I, Section 9, Clause 7 of the Constitution 
 No Money shall be drawn from the Treasury, but in Consequence of Appropriations made by Law; and a regular Statement and Account of the Receipts and Expenditures of all public Money shall be published from time to time . 
 Sec. 3513 . Financial reporting and accounting system 
 -STATUTE- 
 (a) The Secretary of the Treasury shall prepare reports that will inform the President, Congress, and the public on the financial operations of the United States Government. The reports shall include financial information the President requires . The head of each executive agency shall give the Secretary reports and information on the financial conditions and operations of the agency the Secretary requires to prepare the reports . 
 Therefore, the Governmentwide financial reporting for FFATA, TARP, and ARRA are all Constitutionally required to be the responsibility of the Department of the Treasury. Such reporting should be based upon current Federal Agency financial accounting results extracted from Agency Systems of Records that are audited and meet the Federal reporting and internal control requirements of the Financial Systems Integration Office (FSIO) and can be expanded to include reporting for sub tier contractor, grantee, and loan transactions as required by the foregoing legislation 
 
 If the Constitutional reporting requirements are observed, the FFATA, TARP, and ARRA reporting will be integrated into the overall Federal Governmentwide financial management system that integrates Federal Agencies, the Department of the Treasury, and the Office of Management and Budget financial results. This would include not only Federal Award/Expenditure reporting, but also include obligation and performance reporting. Such integration will minimize reconciliation problems that will exist with the disparate reporting by the Federal Agencies, Department of the Treasury, Office of Management and Budget and the Recovery Board as envisioned by the OMB Guidance Memorandum M-09-10 and the OMB Architecture requirements. 
 
 It is foolish for the American Taxpayer to pay for the triplication or quadruplication of Federal financial reporting results. Article I, Section 9, Clause 7 of the Constitution signed on September 17, 1787 fully expected a central Treasury preparation of a " regular Statement and Account of the Receipts and Expenditures of all public Money… " without duplication. Such reporting is presented in the Monthly Treasury Statement and Combined Statement of Receipts, Outlays, and Balances. 
 
 The foregoing consolidated Treasury reporting can be accomplished by accessing existing Federal Agency Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) Core Accounting Systems and expand the use of Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) software for data collection of sub tier contractor, grantee, and loan transactions as required by OMB Circular A-127 and OMB Circular A-130, Section (8)(b)(1)(b) as well as the transparency legislation. In addition the existing FSIO Account Classification Coding Structure provides the standard for Federal financial reporting and is being expanded into a larger civilian agency taxonomy, i.e., Common Governmentwide Account Classification (CGAC) structure complemented by a Standard Financial Information Structure used by the Department of Defense. If the FFATA, EESA/TARP, and ARRA legislation needs any expanded data elements, they can be incorporated into the foregoing current Federal financial taxonomy's. 
 
 To further reduce the overexpansion of the Federal Government's information technology infrastructure, the Treasury Consolidated Governmentwide Financial Management System could reside in the Shared Service Provider (SSP) environment of the National Center for Critical Information Processing and Storage (NCCIPS). Through the use of Enterprise Data Warehouse and parallel processing technology the new SSP could meet scalability and response time requirements related to a virtually limitless requirement for financial and performance data for analysis and query purposes envisioned by the legislation. Finally, a SSP environment meets the OMB Financial Management Line of Business (FMLoB) requirements. 
 
 The Federal Government has financial and technology business and migration plans in the Financial Management Line of Business (FMLoB), Account Classification Code Structure (ACCS), Common Governmentwide Accounting Classification (CGAC) &amp; Standard Financial Information Structure (SFIS), Centers of Excellence (COE), and Shared Service Provider (SSP) initiatives, now is the time to follow the foregoing initiatives and plans and not create new and duplicative financial management reporting requirements. 
 
 Bottom line, place the Federal Government's financial management responsibilities where they are Constitutionally mandated, use the existing FSIO financial management plans, and include ARRA's $800+ Billion, TARP's $700 Billion and FFATA's $1.5 Trillion in expenditures into a comprehensive system. All of the foregoing $3 Trillion in spending will impact the current financial crisis and not just the ARRA funding 
 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/use-of-key-performance-indicators-as-oversight-tool
 
 
 Use of Key Performance Indicators as Oversight Tool
 
 Development of Standardized Key Performance Indicator (KPI) reporting bottoms up: at the recipient/applicant level, at the state level, at the Federal Agency level and, ultimately, for all of ARRA (aggregation of all levels). 
 KPIs can be developed for all relevant programs and act as early warning system/risk assessment method for capuring status of projects and distribution of funds. 
 A KPI framework for ARRA: 
 Using DOT funds (this can be done for all programs) KPI reporting can be developed as follows: 
 Applicant Level - KPI to measure procurement type (e.g. fixed price, unit price, GMP), contract size, original budget, current budget, cost at completion and amounts expended, funding sources, change orders, schedule - NTP, 50% complete and 75% complete, substantial and final completion, requests for information (RFI), % funds reviewed for financial compliance versus amounts submitted for payment, davis bacon compliance 
 State Level - aggregation by applicant, contract type, project type (for testing price), project size, NTP, 50% estimated completion data and final (projected and actual), budget/cost information aggregated by applicant, funding information aggregated by applicant/project typ 
 Federal Level - similar roll up by state/applicant if necessary. 
 ARRA - aggregation of federal agency/state 
 Threshold of acceptability for data points can be used to generate dashboard reporting and act as proactive early warning system of potential non compliance with ARRA requirements/fraud or other desired measurable parameter 
 
 
 This is important as this structure can be scaled quickly once parameters are known. This approach is IT netral: one of many solutions can be used to set up this methodology using thin IT applications. This approach can implemented quickly accross multiple organizations operating differently, procuring differently. This approach extracts mission critical information under a wide range of organizations. THis approach can be developed to be used in reviewing submitted payments using ARRA funds prior to payment and has been used successfully on programs of similar scale. This idea is a key tool in developing risk provides for all levels of ARRA. Tihs idea extracts data needed to test for fraud/abuse.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/lay-a-foundation-for-a-seamless-audit-trail-with-xbrl-gl-and-xml-security
 
 
 Lay a foundation for a seamless audit trail with XBRL GL and XML security
 
 Leverage emerging XML-based standards specifically designed to securely and authentically lay down the foundation for the seamless audit trail 
 
 Leverage the syntax and semantics of XBRL GL - the XBRL Global Ledger Framework (1) - the standardized, single, global, holistic, generic and XBRL-based representation of operational, business and accounting data, including invoices, checks/cheques and other payments, customers and vendors, and other related business facts (2), and the unambiguous link to both underlying transactions (on the source side) through end reports based on XML Schema and XBRL for external reporting. Although there are numerous excellent frameworks for transactions with standardized building blocks that should also be considered, XBRL GL is uniquely designed a.) for historical batches of information, b.) to capture multiple accounting methods simultaneously with full reconciliation and c.) to summarize (roll up) in different ways for different end reporting. 
 
 Use XBRL GL for standardizing data collection from disparate systems, both as a means to monitor transactions in real or near-real time, and to provide complete drill-down data associated with XBRL-based external reports as proof of completeness. 
 
 Support the collaborative development of XML/XBRL-based risk and control information that leverages XBRL GL and XBRL for external reporting (3) and encourage its provision. 
 
 Leverage XML Security standards, including the XML Signature and XML Encryption Recommendations from the W3C (4), to secure confidential information at the data item, rather than file, level. Require extensive filing, but permit encryption of information that may be considered competitively sensitive and personally identifiable information; XML Security at the data field level permits selective unfolding of the information to appropriate parties. 
 
 (1) <a class="external-link" href="http://www.xbrl.org/GLTaxonomy">http://www.xbrl.org/GLTaxonomy</a> 
 (2) <a class="external-link" href="http://gl.iphix.net">http://gl.iphix.net</a> 
 (3) <a class="external-link" href="http://www.oceg.org/Details/GRC-XML">http://www.oceg.org/Details/GRC-XML</a> 
 (4) <a class="external-link" href="http://www.w3.org/2008/xmlsec/">http://www.w3.org/2008/xmlsec/</a> 
 
 The XBRL Global Ledger Framework (XBRL GL) provides a common way to reference, represent and access information that flows into an ERP system or consolidation tool at any point, is integrated anywhere along the audit information supply chain, and provides the drill-down support for end reporting. XBRL GL has been developed to meet the needs of businesses of all sizes, as well as those for whom such standardized representations is important, such as software developers, financial and tax auditors (5) , and others with whom companies wish to or need to exchange such information. XBRL GL has been designed to help facilitate the "seamless audit trail" (6) , even across a diverse data environment, which would be very desirable in today's information environment. 
 
 XBRL GL has the potentially to not only help meet the external transparency requirements of detailed reporting, providing a common face to the payments and other required information, but also can help management have better control of its own information, promoting better internal operations as well. 
 
 Promoting XML Security standards not only moves authentication and privacy from databases, networks and files to documents, it also helps lay a foundation for greater trustworthiness for XBRL external documents and accountability for all manner of internal electronic standards. 
 
 (5) <a class="external-link" href="http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/download.php/14242/OASIS_XML_Position_Paper_for_Tax_Administrations_v2-01.pdf">http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/download.php/14242/OASIS_XML_Position_Paper_for_Tax_Administrations_v2-01.pdf</a> 
 (6) <a class="external-link" href="http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/download.php/16709/Tax%20XML%20AuditTrail_60215.doc">http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/download.php/16709/Tax%20XML%20AuditTrail_60215.doc</a>

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/a-universal-information-access-system-is-the-key-to-stimulus-success
 
 
 A universal information access system is the key to stimulus success
 
 
 
 Just as computers moved from the early 4-bit processors to 32-bit processors so will the 64-bit processors become a standard for all types of devices. This provides an opportunity to create an access system that would require every information source in the system to have a unique 64-bit identifier. With this identifier code a source can assign its unique data identifier and know that in a worldwide database it will remain unique either as public or private information. The distinction between public and private information can be assured by the use of one bit as part of the 64-bit identifier. Access to these documents could be facilitated by the international adoption of phonetic sequences to correspond to new universally constructed symbols identifying less than one hundred characters. Telephone or computer keypads and screen presentations could be controlled by two shift keys, one for information keys and one for local languages. The reason for more information characters than required for 64-bit identifiers is to provide for worldwide address identifiers with greater accuracy than US zip codes and integrated with a GPS system. One category of private records of interest to some in every government is medical records. The next administration will undoubtedly push the computerization of health records. I have recommended the creation of a public-private corporation that would, subject to the Courts, assure the privacy of such records. The individuals using unique identifier only could be entitled to two identifiers. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 My idea addresses the problems of delivery, storage, and retrieval of
the world's knowledge. Just as the world has evolved a universal set of
mathematical symbols and phonetic sequences, it now needs a similar set
for effective universal access to information. By starting now
assigning producers of information a unique identifier and providing
them with a structured 64-bit coded format for their unique
contribution, it would be possible to handle the world's information
resource---providing access to public information and protecting
private information. Implementation of the concept has implications for
US foreign and domestic policy----Peace Corp, education and public
service, and the role of intellectual property in a digital world. As
James Bullington wrote, "Even the best infrastructure projects are only
successful in the long run to the extent they facilitate changes in
people ---new attitudes, new knowledge, new ways of doing things." FSJ
October 2008. 
 The idea is important for the following reasons: 
 1. If the Bush Administration had accepted my proposal (see huc.com) the system could be operating today with the half billion dollars spent on the FBI IT disaster. 
 2. Information is the foundation of civilization. A universal information system can have a positive impact on foreign policy, education, health information systems, and on all apects of social and economic policy.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/information-mgt-disciplines-trusted-transparency
 
 
 Information Mgt Disciplines = Trusted Transparency
 
 As a veteran of many efforts that enable widespread information access (i.e., "transparency") to some of the largest, most complex and most diverse information environments in the world, Teradata is well acquainted with the challenges inherent in not only standing up an initial system but also in the accommodating the ongoing maintenance and expansion demands that will undoubtedly come from end users wanting more and more information. If it's one thing we've learned from end users, the initial questions are only precursors for many, many more. 
 Experience has taught us that providing "trusted" transparency in an "ecosystem" of millions of transactions being executed by thousands of individuals representing 1000's of organizations both public and private, along with their disparate organizational and technical capabilities requires a common set of "nomenclatures" by which all activities are ultimately governed by. Contractors, Suppliers, Agencies, Individuals, Policy codes, Accounting codes,.…..all need to be identified, maintained and communicated in such a way that proper transparency and decision making can be executed with the upmost confidence in the data being used. Failure to do this will only lead to "fact-based chaos". 
 The reality of providing this capability is daunting when one considers the vastness of the people, processes, organizations and technology involved and the realization that it is impossible to assume that processes and systems can be conformed in total to provide the consistency of information exchange required. To address this reality, there are several imperatives that the Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board should consider when setting direction on how to accomplish such a task: 
 · Centralization of data onto a common data model - this solution cannot be delivered by stringing together a series of independent systems and databases - the associated integration and maintenance costs along with the data inconsistencies make anything but a centralized model absolutely impractical. 
 · Centralized governance of business rules and policies regarding information exchange WITH a distributed, self-service model for ensuring conformance among participating agencies and organizations. In short, in order for organizations to participate in any funding and transacting, they will need to become good "stewards" of the information by keeping up with any necessary correction, cross-referencing, etc. of information before it can be deemed "accepted" into the centralized system used for analysis and reporting. 
 · Significant leverage of available data quality and standardization tools &amp; services to reduce the amount of manual intervention required to address data conformance issues. Tools that allow a system to identify when data has been incorrectly entered and possibly even self-correct the data based on pre-defined policies and rules can significantly improve the quality of the data while reducing the time required to maintain that quality. 
 · Implementation of Data Quality audits. These DQ audits should be "instrumented" directly into the centralized system and as part of the overall governance process executed by the IGs. The DQ audit should effectively report on the policies and rules established for the various data subject areas (e.g. Contractors, Suppliers, Agencies, Individuals, Policy codes, Accounting codes, etc). 
 · Think incremental development steps. Boiling the ocean doesn't work. Development priorities should be set in a manner that allows increasing functionality to be delivered every 60-90 days. 
 · Pay attention to the human change management dimensions of this effort. The technology, while daunting, is easier than the human/organization/behavioral aspects. 
 
 
 With respect to the Recovery.Gov effort, we feel that it is vital that the central information foundation adhere to consistent definitions as it is used to provide organizations and individuals with appropriate insights into the usage of funds and to support the detection of fraud and waste. Otherwise, the credibility, and thus any hope of real transparency, will be lost immediately, resulting in un-told negative reactions and political consequences.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/recovery-gov-needs-to-be-accessible-and-understandable-to-the-public
 
 
 Recovery.gov Needs to be Accessible and Understandable to the Public
 
 Data on on the Recovery.gov website should be displayed in a manner that allows non-expert users to easily observe the flow of federal funds and the impact those funds are having. Two dimensions should be paramount in making decisions how to display information on Recovery.gov: data knowledge of the user and technology skills of the user. Recovery.gov should serve those at the low end of both dimensions, but not at the expense of the high end for each dimension. At a minimum, the data should be searchable by: - Recipients (including all tiers of subrecipients) of federal funds - Geography (state, congressional district, street address, ZIP code, census tract) - Project type - Federal agency - Number and type of jobs - Dollar amount - Other criteria 
 Further, Federal spending data should be displayed in a format similar, but not necessarily identical to the federal government's USASpending.gov. Although the user interface of the site could be improved, it should serve as the basis for how the data should be displayed. The principle is that the public should be able to search by federal agency, company, state or city, for example, to obtain aggregate information and then drill down on specific transactions. 
 
 While access to raw data through feeds and other technologies is important to measure the success of the Recovery.gov website and the overall stimulus effort, the true test of whether this transparency can be used as an accountability tool will be the extent to which the public engages in monitoring and tracking the stimulus implementation. Without the public's involvement, the ability to hold those in power accountable using the data that will be available on Recovery.gov will be limited. Having a site that is accessible and understandable for the public is crucial to realizing the goals being this unprecedented level of government transparency. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/oregon-stimulus-transparency-accountability-tracking-system
 
 
 Oregon Stimulus Transparency &amp; Accountability Tracking System
 
 A high degree of transparency and accountability is expected in the way the American Recovery &amp; Reinvestment Act funds are spent. The Oregon Stimulus Transparency &amp; Accountability Tracking System (ORSTATS) is one of the key tools to provide that transparency and accountability. ORSTATS includes three primary components: 
 · a database to capture information about stimulus expenditures 
 · a reporting tool to monitor individual projects and programs 
 · a mapping tool to visualize the data and track the impact of stimulus funds 
 Transparency is our ability to see where stimulus funded activities are taking place in Oregon. Accountability is seeing that stimulus dollars are spent responsibly and JOBS ARE CREATED or PRESERVED in the locations where the dollars are spent. 
 Governor Kulongoski's Economic Recovery Executive Team (ERET) has declared that ORSTATS is the single system for planning, tracking and reporting on all stimulus expenditures for which the Governor's Office and state agencies have reporting responsibilities, regardless of which agency or organization receives recovery funds. The ERET has also made this system available to local governments and other ARRA fund recipients for their use in planning, tracking and reporting stimulus expenditures. 
 The web-based maps and information will allow state agencies and local governments to plan, track, and report on stimulus spending to achieve the greatest possible impact. The web-based maps will allow Oregonians to see how and where economic stimulus funds are spent and the economic impact of those expenditures on their communities. 
 ORSTATS will provide agencies the ability to plan where stimulus dollars are spent based on the greatest likely impact. In some cases, that will be the potential for creating jobs, but it could also be the potential for lowering crime rates, hunger, homelessness, or student-teacher ratios, or perhaps raising student proficiency levels. 
 Once the dollars have been spent, ORSTATS will provide agencies the ability to track and report on many measures of impact. Visualizing potential and actual impact on a map provides a quick and easily understandable picture of stimulus effectiveness for government agencies and the public. 
 
 
 Knowing where stimulus dollars are spent is the only way to track the impact of those dollars in relationship to the problems they are intended to resolve, like unemployment, crime, hunger, homelessness, improved education, sustainabile energy development, etc.

There is also private group use -- please see www.reengineeringllc.com/terms_and_conditions.html . src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/create-and-provide-a-basis-for-cost-performance-comparisons-or-benchmarks
 
 
 Create and provide a basis for cost/performance comparisons or benchmarks
 
 Ultimately, the recovery act is about creating jobs in a way that's better than paying people $XX thousands of dollars per year for meaningless tasks. Some programs may create jobs at a cost of several times what other programs will cost...Recovery.gov should not just let people see what the cost differences, but should provide a standard for comparison and display variances from the standard or benchmark. For example, if the Recovery Act creats a broadband or health IT job, did the average overhead cost for creating the job cost 20% or 120% of the total annual wages for that job? What jobs cost more to create? After this data is published, people will have a basis for reviewing and understanding effectiveness and efficiency of Recovery Act spending. 
 
 People are going to be shocked at what it costs the government to create some jobs, but need to context to have a valid review. Providing benchmarks or standards will help people understand the cost of job creation, while focusing criticism on outliers. If standards or benchmarks are created, people will also be able to investigate inappropriate behavior or wasteful programs that show up as excess costs for creating a job.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/trust-enablement-metamodel
 
 
 Trust Enablement Metamodel
 
 You asked for ideas and approaches for a 
 
 Metamodel
 for Recovery.gov that considers data models used by source systems 
 Recovery.org should provide a suite of infrastructure services that, regardless of the site's content or the user community it serves, all services delivered provide maximum value to stakeholders. 
 Principles 
 A trust-enabling infrastructure should be guided by principles. For example: 
 Improving trust in the information provided by recovery.org can produce significant social, political and economic benefits; A trust strategy will be a component of recovery.org's overall information delivery strategy; A trust-enabling services infrastructure will support all information facilitated by recovery.org; The trust-enabling services infrastructure will be reusable, based on consistently defined frameworks (organization, policies, standards, procedures, methodologies, as well as services and technologies) that can be shared consistently throughout recovery.org on behalf of the users (human and technology-based) of its infrastructure services; and The trust-enabling services infrastructure will be sufficiently flexible to evolve and adapt to changes in the environment and government objectives. 
 Framework 
 The trust-enabling infrastructure should be structured based on a metamodel that comprehensively defines the high level considerations required to achieve specific trust objectives. An example is the Trust Enablement Framework, described starting on page 13 of "<a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/local/Trust_Measures_and_Indicators_for_Customers.pdf">Trust Measures and Indicators for Customers</a>". The document describes, and provides examples for, each element of the framework, explaining how they contribute to achieving specific trust and business objectives. 
 Metamodel 
 The following is an illustrative example of a metamodel for creating subordinate data models, based on the Trust Enablement Framework described in the document above: 
 Experiential Sources of Trust (transparency) 
 Reporting of anomalies Transaction tracking Feedback forums Escrow services Performance Verification Identity verification Support responsiveness Fulfillment metrics Tracking status of applications/proposals Satisfaction with funding process Comparative economic impacts Privacy protection experiences Confirmations of transactions Access to person offline etc. 
 Interpretive Sources of Trust (expert opinions) 
 Provision of adequate information User awareness program Seals of approval Known merchant seals Security and Privacy seals Brands Security &amp; Privacy policies on web site Presentation Regional/cultural perspectives Service/performance opinions and grading Value appraisals Quality of service rating Fair, ethical and responsible business principles assertions Published FAQ/Help Available technical support Rating of site and services Assurance rating Disclosure of funding sources Supporting brands Co-branding Frequently Asked Questions Assertions of competence Assertions of fairness Associations and affiliations Reputation etc. 
 Empowerment (choice) 
 Reliable providers of feedback Referral to other sources Evaluating recommenders Links from other trusted sites Recommendations from other sources Introduction &amp; matching services Voting Opting out etc. 
 Motive Forces (rules) 
 Redress mechanisms Rules for information protection Laws and/or regulations that protect privacy Governance structures and practices Recourse mechanisms Business policies and practices Safe harbour investigations Disallowed conduct and services Dispute resolution IP Infringement policy Commitment Organization's integrity Values of participants Ethical standards Enforceability of conduct Regulations Culture Common social or legal code Community member interdependence (continuity) Motivation to deliver value Individual ethics Organizational charter Incentives etc. 
 Proficiency (ability) 
 Security controls Current technology IT scalability Privacy controls Dependable technology Knowledgeable and competent staff Operational resources Reliable processes Information protection functionality Information validation functionality Secure infrastructure Operational resiliency Ability to deliver expected value Controls on use of information etc. 
 Risk Transference 
 Contract formation Liability protection User agreement Fraud protection insurance Satisfaction guarantee Warranties Insurance Credit protection Fiduciary responsibilities Privacy guarantee Confidentiality guarantee Identity theft guarantee Accountability Inducements etc. 
 
 
 Content is valuable only when it contains relevant, new information
that can be relied upon to improve decisions-making. The quantity and
quality of content alone is therefore not going to be sufficient to
make recovery.org a success. A well-designed trust-enabling
infrastructure, defined as part of the baseline metamodel, can
significantly contribute to the value delivered to each user and the
business outcome. A trust-enabling infrastructure should help to
establish (develop) trust by introducing relying parties to intrinsic
(experiential) and extrinsic (interpretive) sources of trust, and
enabling them to identify and leverage their preferred source(s) of
trust in order to sufficiently validate all the information being relied upon to form opinions and make
decisions. The trust-enabling infrastructure should also help to ensure
(preserve) trust by protecting relying parties with governance
services, risk sharing services, controls, and processes that ensure
the continued reliability of information. It seeks to appropriately balance requirements for control with aspirations for trust.
