src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/build-an-approval-validated-system-for-data
 
 
 Build an Approval / Validated system for data
 
 As Government transparency matures a large majority of the information being shared will likely be "digital data", i.e. more then ust documents we will have facts &amp; figures, some automatically generated as well as "expert statements". 
 I'd like a system by which we could provide a tag to such data to help highlight it's "truthie-ness". 
 I'd like to know which experts may (dis)approve of a statement or legislation as well as have a sense of trust associated when I'm given a number. 
 As examples; 
 1) If someone issues a statement that "Solving &lt;X&gt; will cost $90 million" I'd like to know who agrees, and who disagrees and be able to find (directly from the data) the various opinion. 
 2) Or if I'm told the USPS saved $10 million in fuel costs by switching to a more optimized delivery system and cutting out Thursday deliveries I'd like to know if any experts have vouched for that number and what the margin for error is. 
 
 As policy and decisions will be increasingly decided based on data driven analysis and visualizations. It's critical that those numbers are not simply pulled from thin air and that we can discern the pedigree of such statments.

 Build an Approval / Validated system for data
 
 
 We need a system of linking and commentary on statements and data. 
 For example if someone says "This will save us $10M" I'd like to know who agrees or disagrees and how they derived that number. 
 And if the USPS says they'll save $8M by utilizing more fuel efficient routes and not delivering mail on Tuesdays" then I want to know whether or not that's been checked by an independent 3rd party. 
 
 As more "data driven" decisions are made based on analytics and visualizations it's critical that we develop a "pedigrie" for this data so we can associate a level of trust, assurance and accountability for the actions they drive.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/empower-an-organization-to-simplify-the-data-environment
 
 
 Empower AN Organization to simplify the data environment
 
 The key missing element is a Single Organization responsible for rationalizing and driving consistency in the mess of state, local, and federal government data systems affected by Recovery.gov. The business issue was locked-in back in the 1980s New Federalism, which firmly established the delivery channel whereby the Federal government got out of most direct service delivery. Since then, the feds have shifted to relying on state and local government as their delivery partner. Although the federal government has required bills be sent-in, with some level of reports and auditing, the systems used to create, recieve, and process the bills were never built to work together. This is what is inhibiting the accountability and transparency of the federal programs covered under the Recovery Act (ARRA). 
 Concepts such as Master Data Management (MDM) and Semantic Web being discussed here are very important for the success fo Recovery.gov. In essence, these are data architecture constructs that would let Recovery.gov use existing data sources, dramatically reducing the burden on government, universities, and others who must submit reports. For example, MDM would reduce data errors due to semantic issues and other inconsistencies in systems used by those having to submit reports. Semantic web concepts would reduce middleware and Business Intelligence, visualization, and other costs of acquiring and using the data. 
 However, deploying these concepts is not free, and a strong federal leadership focal point is required to deal with those would resist transparency by keeping data in customized formats. In addition, the federal government would have to figure out an effective deployment strategy, which would involve a snow-balling effect...perhaps by requiring modification to the standard federal receivables format (at least bill presentment), the performance/results report submitted with the bill (building on or simplifying the current earned value reqt), and accounts payable data string. This would save a lot of money all levels of govt are spending on administration and to comply with Recovery.gov reporting reqts. But, since the money is so dispersed, the value may only make sense when aggregated across the silos of government...which in itself requires a single point of leadership to make the case for change and lead the change. 
 I am proposing that the federal organization overseeing Recovery.gov shifting from a report receiver to a good management leader. 
 
 The vast majority of the concepts being discussed here on the National Dialogue assume that there is a single leader that can drive change. That's wrong, unless something changes. Recovery.gov is operating on a reporting structure that sits on top of non-transparent systems. Getting disparate systems to report consistently or putting on a filter that makes disparate data look alike is a bandaid approach to bigger problems (resistance to transparency and systems that were never built to communciate), and many bandaids recommended here may be the most expensive way for the government to proceed. If the government can get accountability and transparency for $787B, we can get it for the vast majority of spending. 
 Today, the leadership is only driving the reporting requirements. But, many entities fear transparency and others fear the cost and burden of reporting. This implies ARRA recipients can't afford to report well or may not want to report with the right data. As a result, getting good data is expensive and Recovery.gov even has envisioned a "Reconciliation Solution," which cannot be cheap and will generate controversial results. 
 Let's fix this at the root cause, by changing the focus of the feds and taking the time to do it right. If someone did the business case, i bet we'd see substantial savings as well as true transparency and accountability. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/use-existing-commercial-saas-enterprise-solutions-for-decentralized-model
 
 
 Use Existing Commercial SaaS Enterprise Solutions for Decentralized Model
 
 This morning I published a simple twitter post that circulated quickly. The post was inspired by a Washington Post article on the Johnstown Pa airport. According to the Post article, the airport, though slightly used, became one of the first recipients of stimulus funds and has now received over 200M of federal money over a period of 10 years.

The twitter entry clearly hit a nerve. What I said was:

"The Johnstown airport is a good example of why social media is so important to achieving transparency." I also said: "Spending intellectual capital simply to publish info is missing the whole point of transparency: better decisions."

Here is what I meant.

 Old World Transparency 

Under the Economic Recovery Act, the federal government, in Title XV requires every state to collect data on transparency projects, and to publish that data in a master portal - Recovery.gov. Presumably, state and local governments are going to spend many tens (perhaps hundreds) of millions of dollars to meet transparency requirements defined in this way as they collect and save data, build large data warehouses and schemas, and do everything that it takes to comply with such a massive data engineering challenge.

The Economic Recovery Act requirement is essentially an "Old World" view of transparency. We can publish contract information on projects under the banner of transparency to an extreme. We can even enable public comment on data collected. But what will be accomplished? And at what cost? What is novel, or new about this old world model?

The Economic Recovery Act essentially establishes requirements for government organizations in much the same way that Sarbanes Oxley did for businesses. The underlying intent, as in Sarbanes Oxley was a good one - namely that through publication, organizations have incentive to be compliant and accountable to their stakeholders. But publication standing alone misses the point.

Under an "Old World" transparency model, the government agency acts outside of the network publishing information from the outside in.

 New World Transparency. 

In contrast, in a "New World" transparency model, government agencies act "in network" providing information from within to all citizens and stakeholders and then enabling those stakeholders and citizens to discuss and exchange the information with ever evolving solution possibilities. The power of "in-network" models is exponential. There are many studies in commercial markets that conclude that consumers (citizens) are up to 9 times more likely to act on the advice and exchange of their peers.

So how does this apply to transparency for stimulus and the Economic Recovery Act? Here is how.

Transparency has many dimensions. In the case of the Johnstown airport, and transparency projects like it, let's say that all of the contract data is published. What is the consequence? The money has been allocated and spent. We might bring scrutiny after the fact. We might provide disincentives to future expenditures, though undoubtedly whoever is responsible for decision making was able to rationalize the expenditure.

Alternatively, what if social media were used to establish public views on alternative expenditures - perhaps in exactly the same area of Pennsylvania? If we said to the people of Pennsylvania - here is 2M or 200M of federal dollars, how would you spend it to create jobs in the region - are we confident that they would say "the Johnstown runway and airport"? Or might they say something else? Might we uncover alternative solution possibilities before the fact of expenditure so that choices are proactively, not reactively made? That is where social media can be helpful.

Social media can present alternatives on a local basis in a relatively short period of time. It can be used to gather ideas between and amongst alternatives. And it can be used to qualitatively, not only quantitatively, evaluate different ideas. In other words it can present decision makers with a clearer view of solution possibilities so that the "best" decision is made. This is no small deal.

In other words, transparency has another dimension. It isn't simply defined by telling citizens what you are going to do and how much you have spent after the fact. It is involving them before decisions are made and along the way. Transparency in this sense creates citizen ownership and true involvement - not just sending a comment along on a federal agency Web site.

 Dimensional Transparency is Critical to the Future of Government and Citizen Trust 

There could not be a more critical challenge than for government to get transparency "right". Think of the challenge this way. For every federal dollar that adds to the deficit and that does not improve productivity, our global competitive position is eroded in exactly the same way as if that dollar was spent in banking or financial bailouts, or any other expenditure that does not lead to production of goods and services.

Dollars wasted don't ultimately put more people to work. Every dollar of stimulus expenditure has to count. Dollars that do not add to productivity will cause inflation and a weakening in the global position of the US Dollar. So government stimulus expenditures have to be effective. We have to get the most out of every dollar.

In the case of Johnstown airport and many stimulus projects like it, will transparency accomplish its intended purpose? One scenario from a citizen perspective might be: "You had all of these transparency requirements, published contract information, and still wasted the money." The irony could be that narrowly defined transparency could actually lead to less not more citizen trust.

In contrast, if we broaden our view of transparency to promote true citizen inclusion through citizen networks established locally, on a decentralized basis, then citizens will become a part of establishing priorities, will take broader ownership of stimulus spending and the projects that it funds, and will be responsible for defining alternatives. Even if projects fail, or are sub-optimal, at least citizens will have had an opportunity for true inclusion. That is the type of behavior that will build trust and accountability.

How many more Washington Post/New York Times articles await us on stimulus funded projects that make little economic sense to the populous of citizens? Worse still, how many blog or SM exposes await? And won't those articles inevitably erode citizen trust in the face of transparency - and possibly create an even more dramatic crisis in citizen confidence?

Like many readers, my first reaction to the WP article was one of affirmation - that this is the way that the federal government often works. Further, stimulus funds are going to be spent just as all federal funds are spent - often without accountability and broader purpose.

That is why social media should be used now to provide decentralized involvement in state and local citizen networks. Social media and citizen networks will ultimately build the trust that transparency through publication under the Economic Recovery Act so desperately seeks.
 
 
 
 This idea is important because to be effective in achieving transparency, there must be citizen involvement in decentralized project based environments. Citizens are much more likely (by over 65%) to engage in state and local project involvement than in a federal portal based environment. 
 The Software as a Service solutions to support this are proven and in use today in both public and private sector environments.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/push-versus-pull-for-oversight-of-funds
 
 
 Push versus Pull for oversight of funds
 
 Enable the oversight agencies and the public to "pull" data and information via a "cloud computing" paradigm. Through web services API standards all agencies would be able to populate the "cloud" with relative ease. The information in the cloud would then be available to anyone based upon their need and requirements. 
 
 The traditional method used to gather information for reporting purposes is a "push" method where agencies are required to provide data at certain times, in certain formats to create a centralized data repository. The problem is that these systems are extremely complex and expensive to build and maintain requiring standardization and centralization of systems and processes across an extremely varied set of agencies, missions and services. Therefore, it puts the government in a position to fail even before they begin. Its like asking 15 completely different commercial organizations from different industries to do the same thing - impossible. Utilizing the cloud computing method you are able to place information in a cloud from any source at any time through API interface standards thereby reducing the impact and cost to the government. Then the oversight agencies and public can "pull" data at any time making trasparency possible. The "pulling" method is faster, better and cheaper enabling the government to be in the business of oversight versus the business of data collection and management under the current more traditional, expensive and inefficient "push" method. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/online-modeling
 
 
 Online modeling
 
 Models provide an ideal means for encoding a wide range of individual theories on a problem. For the Recovery effort there are already a lot of ideas and policies for stimulating the economy and transforming agencies (energy, education, healthcare, etc). Simulation models will allow policy makers to formalize their theory, link it to data, and then forecast the expected effects. This will allow for a very objective way to determine which programs actually work and which do not.
 
 
Currently there is no true online modeling environment. At best there are some clients that allow you to create models offline and then publish an executable online (see an overly simplistic example on historic GDP <a class="external-link" href="http://feedbackgovernsdyanmics.blogspot.com/2009/04/very-simple-gdp-model.html">here</a>
 ). The problem with this however is that the most important part, the model structure, is then invisible and therefore not open to scrutiny and modification. 
 
 The Recovery provides a perfect opportunity to develop an online modeling tool that can be used by research communities in concert with policy makers to create simulation models exploring different problems and potential solutions. 
 
 There have been a lot of ideas on how to open source the data in the Recovery effort, but this is only the beginning (<a class="external-link" href="linked-open-data">Tim Berners-Lee's post</a> is a good example). In order to truly make sense of all this data, researchers and policy makers need a more robust means for formalizing theories and ideas. Visualization and analysis tools do help with communicating results, but they don't always capture the structure of the problem and proposed solutions. What is needed is a way to open source the theory . 
 Simulation models fill this gap by explicitly mapping out the causal structures thought to be creating a problem or providing a solution. The complex challenges posed in the Recovery effort can only be met using the science of systems to break down, model, and test the wide variety of ideas being proposed. 
 Models are also very good at both aggregating and disaggregating data. For example, the overall spending in the Recovery effort could be modeled, but then linked to disaggregated models of individual program areas. This would allow anyone from layman to experts to examine information that is appropriate to their interests. 
 The development of this tool will not only help with the Recovery effort, it will revolutionize the way complex problems are solved, ushering in a new era of scientifc rigor and responsibility.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/use-of-trns2022port-bams-dss-software-in-39-dots
 
 
 Use of Trns•port BAMS/DSS software in 39 DOTs
 
 The AASHTO Trns•port ® software system is a set of integrated components designed to meet highway/transportation agency pre-construction and construction contract information and management needs. Trns•port BAMS/DSS® is widely regarded as the premier software product for the analysis of transportation construction project data and is used in 38 states and Washington DC. BAMS/DSS provides a complete Trns•port historical database specifically designed to provide decision support in the areas of bid monitoring and evaluation, vendor (contractor, subcontractor, and DBE) and market analysis, and item price estimation. Other Trns•port systems monitor additional relevant road construction project activities, such as daily work, contractor payments, and subcontractor information. Data from the other Trns•port systems is archived into the BAMS/DSS historical data warehouse for ad hoc reporting and a wide variety of trend analyses. 
 Info Tech, Inc., the contractor for Trns•port, first developed BAMS/DSS in the early 1980s and has more than 30 years experience with fraud and competition data analysis. The software provides state DOTs with the data and tools to perform contract monitoring with analytical models that look for patterns suggestive of fraud and collusive behaviors, allowing them to address potential problems before they get out of control. Info Tech, Inc. also provides data analysis services and training to state DOTs to assist them with their fraud detection and prevention efforts. Road construction data analysis services that are relevant to ARRA projects vigilance include, but are not limited to, pre-award contract analysis and road construction major item cost tracking. Experience has shown that DOTs - with ongoing proactive contract monitoring procedures in place - typically receive more competition and lower prices. To date, Info Tech estimates that it has saved or recovered in excess of $1B for public agencies. 
 More information on AASHTO Trns•port software can be found at 
 <a href="http://www.aashtoware.org/?siteid=28&amp;pageid=73"> http://www.aashtoware.org/?siteid=28&amp;pageid=73 </a> 
 More information on Info Tech, Inc. can be found at <a href="http://www.infotechfl.com/"> http://www.infotechfl.com/ </a> 
 
 
 The Trns•port BAMS/DSS software system, historical data warehouse, and analytical procedures are already in use in 39 US Departments of Transportation. This tool can be used to monitor ARRA road construction projects with very little or no start-up costs.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/take-this-opportunity-to-benefit-from-real-enterprise-architecture
 
 
 Take this opportunity to benefit from real enterprise architecture
 
 Emergencies can cause people and organizations to do extraordinary things, including taking on issues and opportunities that are the "right thing to do" but in normal times somehow never get done. We see this now in many areas or the President's program for national recovery, including economic stimulus, health care reform, and energy. The Administration should extend these calls for immediate action and change to processes around how government designs and acquires information technology solutions. Several important IT/IS management initiatives are directly applicable, including the discipline of using enterprise architecture to guide the full life cycle of acquiring solutions to meet business needs and required careful consideration of cost-effective alternatives to custom development, such as shared interagency solutions and their COTS/SOA-enabled/and SaaS brethern. Why not take this opportunity for OMB's CIO to apply this model using current federal enterprise architecture reference models to spending that is proposed on new information system solutions. This activity would pay for itself over time, and to address the current emergency and the need for immediate action, could be funded by recovery funds (including a small part of the planned budget for recovery.gov, if necessary) and staffed at least in part through details from participating agencies. 
 
 A large fraction of the $72+ billion now spent every year by federal agencies on information and technology management solutions is wasted on redundant, duplicative, and non-interoperable systems and solutions, and recovery-funded programs threaten to add many more billions to this waste. Serious application of real enterprise architecture by the new federal CIO could be done quickly and have an immediate effect in reducing this waste, to increase the benefit of emergency spending and bring lasting change to how the federal government manages the acquisition and use of expensive information and technology management solutions.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/professional-development-and-training-opportunities-in-emerging-tech
 
 
 Professional Development and Training Opportunities in Emerging Tech
 
 Provide grant and funding opportunities for professionals working in the IT field within academia to further their education and expand their knowledge of cutting edge technologies. 
 A more bottom-up approach needs to be made to help modernize and improve the information technologies being used in todays research colleges and universities. 
 In order to develop expertise and proficiency using emerging technologies, you need to have the resources to attend conferences, training and make use of other educational outreach opportunities. There are a myriad of IT technologies that are in the R&amp;D stages as well as RTM phases. There are few to no higher-ed courses that are teaching these newer technologies.  To get familiar with these emerging technologies, an IT professional needs to attend conferences and interact with other industry professionals that are developing these technologies. Attending technology conferences, however, tends to be relatively expensive, with money being harder to find these days. 
 
 Many of the faculty and administrators consult with the IT professionals and developers in their institutions to solicit guidance and expertise regarding hardware and software technologies that are suitable for a given task or research project. The options that an IT professional can propose are directly related to their exposure and familiarity with a given technology.

The problem is that grants and/or other funding opportunities do not seem to be available for these same IT professionals and developers. Have a look through Grants.gov and the like and the opportunities tend to be earmarked for students and faculty. 
 Other professionals have requirements for continued education as part of their professional development. Classes that they can take to remain up-to-date in their profession. Academic IT professionals and developers are no different - they should be given the resources and opportunities that they need to thrive and innovate. 
 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/publish-and-hold-accountable-measurable-business-results
 
 
 Publish and hold accountable measurable business results 
 
 For each allocation of funds there should be a clear set of measurable business results that define success for the use of those funds. The results should be described in SMART terminology (specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, time-based) and should form the basis of the business case on why the allocation of funds is a good idea, 
 The expected results should be clearly agreed and published before any expenditure of funds, and tracked - this information should be made available to the public through recovery.gov

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/search-that-will-enable-the-national-dialogue
 
 
 Search that will enable the national dialogue.
 
 The idea is simple. Search. Search and you will find. Search and you will discover. Search makes information visual and actionable. Search is the enabler to make information transparent and accessible to all. Search that is contextually aware of the citizen, their constituency, their location, their social economic status -- what makes this person uniquely matter to our great nation -- is what is needed. When you are in an unlinked world of databases, reports, spreadsheets, and reams of unstructured content, you need the right search solution. <a class="external-link" href="http://www.microsoft.com/enterprisesearch/en/us/fast.aspx">FAST Search </a>has been enabling governments and commercial organizations make the most of their information for years - placing structure and order on your data to create information and intelligence. And now, as part of <a class="external-link" href="http://www.microsoft.com/enterprisesearch/en/us/why-enterprise-search.aspx">Microsoft</a>, we are opening a new chapter in <a class="external-link" href="http://www.microsoft.com/enterprisesearch/en/us/what-is-enterprise-search.aspx">enterprise search</a>. 
 This is not a new idea. Government agencies have been using search for years to deliver up to the minute intelligence, real time data analysis, situational awareness, and a host of other mission critical applications. Organizations have been using search to drive revenue by developing new commerce models, deliver engaging experiences with their customers, and connecting with their supply chains. Search has been the one true enabling technology to make sense of the massive data collection known as the World Wide Web. 
 Search allows organizations to create a single model of its data, leveraging existing metadata, as well as dynamically extracting and identifying entities and relationships from the broad context of the unstructured content. With virtually unlimited scalability, the unified search index creates a normalized representation of all of your data that acts as the middleware to a host of applications that are contextually aware of citizens, their locations, their interests, their needs, and can dynamically reflect the changing world around them. Finally, search provides a complete set of application programming interfaces (APIs) for content ingestion, dissemination, and retrieval. 
 Search is entering a new phase. Search is becoming pervasive. Search is no longer about a simple text box that returns a list of the most popular results. Search can now orchestrate a dynamic user experience by understanding the context of the user question, leveraging the available clues to the user's intent from social, application, and process interactions, and executing underlying contextual matching and data access algorithms capable of returning rich interface experiences in real time. Today, search incorporates not only broad intelligence about all forms of data and process inside the enterprise, but also continuous connection to the surrounding data and service environments of the Web, mobile, consumer entertainment, and governments. 
 
 
 The goal of Recovery.gov is to create a useful portal for citizens requires finding innovative ways to integrate, track, and display data from thousands of federal, state, and local entities. This is exactly what enterprise search is designed to do. In fact, search is the glue that will tie the magic of software with the power of internet services across a world of devices. The <a class="external-link" href="http://msstudios.vo.llnwd.net/o21/presspass/zune/AGlimpseAhead_Zune.wmv">future </a>will rely on a transparent set of services that will evoke transformational change to government and industry and it will all be driven by enterprise search. 
 This is important because we as a nation need a solution -- the right solution. One that will work and be sustainable for future generations. One that will put America back in the driver's seat of the world's economy. One that will truly make a difference.

 automate the collection of allegations from multiple hotline sources and formats into one fraud case management system; analyze the allegations to identify patterns and trends and to determine which cases need to be investigated through the use of sophisticated data mining and business intelligence tools; and manage not only the operational and technical processes, but the business processes to quickly assemble comprehensive information, review allegations and adjudicate cases.  Alerts and notifications (as cited in other ideas) are required to identify early problems and non-obvious relationships and predictive analytics are needed to target and prevent potential fraud, waste and abuse. It is possible to include many of these requirements into a sophisticated, yet configurable fraud case management system without the delay in building a customized solution.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/reducing-infrastructure-waste-one-size-fits-all-wont-work
 
 
 Reducing Infrastructure Waste - One size fits all won't work
 
 The data necessary to measure the effectiveness of construction-related spending on transportation, infrastructure, new buildings, renovations and energy retrofit programs are very different than the data required to measure the effectiveness of other stimulus-related programs like COBRA supplements or job training programs. A "one size fits all" approach to tracking ARRA spending will fall short of expectations. With the bulk of ARRA funds directed at construction-related programs, this area represents the highest risk for waste, fraud and abuse or the greatest opportunity for a return on investment. 
 
 Standardizing reporting requirements for construction-related spending will enable governments to rapidly identify projects that are at risk for waste, fraud or abuse and ensure corrective action is taken. As a first phase, this can be done relatively rapidly, low cost/low tech, and does not have to be nor should be burdensome to the industry. 
 
 Construction companies already collect key data points using commercial-off-the-shelf systems as part of managing projects whether they are highways, roads, bridges or buildings. Key data points, when viewed individually or in aggregate form, can help the government rapidly identify red flags that indicate a project is at risk, mitigate issues before they become problems, and identify best practices that should be shared. 
 
 Several effective commercial, off-the-shelf systems also exist for organizing, analyzing and visualizing this data which minimizes the need for customization. A well considered, scalable solution can also be repurposed as a standard reporting tool across agencies for future construction spending - stretching taxpayer dollars even further. 
 
 Developing technology requirements for internal RAAT board purposes and external recovery.gov transparency requirements requires further consideration. How, whether or not, and when data are shared with the public presents opportunities as well as risks. While transparency is a worthy and achievable goal, there is a real risk that citizen, media and other analysts lacking domain expertise may draw inaccurate conclusions about data. This in turn could create policy, privacy, administrative and legal issues with the potential to undermine the administration's goals for recovery.gov. The CompStat model Mr. Devaney favors in fact, includes both public and "behind the wall" components for these very reasons. 
 
 Finally, 3D, data-rich, parametric technology known as "Building Information Modeling" (BIM) and related technologies like clash detection are rapidly gaining traction in the construction industry. When 3D technologies are combined with work process changes, they deliver better quality projects, up to 15 percent ahead of schedule with cost savings of up to 20 percent. 
 
 The GSA, Army Corps of Engineers, Department of State and Veterans Affairs all now require BIM for larger projects and adoption rates are beginning to increase at the local and state level - particularly among transportation agencies. When you consider that 10-20 percent of the budget for most transportation projects in the United States is dedicated to rework - correcting mistakes or addressing unforeseen issues that 2D technologies can't catch, - encouraging adoption of 3D technologies provided that data collection standards are developed in tandem would help further stretch taxpayer dollars and drastically reduce waste. 
 
 Construction-related spending represents the largest share of ARRA funding, the greatest risk for waste and the greatest opportunity for ROI. Technologies used by the industry today if combined with government standards can help the government maximize ROI, transparency and accountability. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/add-geographic-and-semantic-dimensions-to-existing-data-with-georss-atom
 
 
 Add geographic and semantic dimensions to existing data with GeoRSS / Atom
 
 Providing dimensional attributes to existing information and information systems has usually been a slow and heavy-weight process, especially for multiple dimensions such as space and time. The Atom Web Feed information format, combined with GeoRSS geoenabling tags and Web linking technologies, provides a lightweight, rapid, and agile means of adding such dimensions and achieving the visual-analytical insights they can provide. 
 While these tools are typically used for geo-enabling, or adding geographic context to information, the GML version of GeoRSS also allows arbitrary specification of coordinate reference systems. This means that GeoRSS / Atom can as well define attributes representing multiple semantic dimensions (cost, performance, equitability, demographics, etc.) useful for visualizing and working with government data. Call it geography plus. 
 
 
 It is too often the case that ideas for understanding information in new ways founder on the inability or slowness of existing information systems to accommodate them. GeoRSS + Atom offers an opportunity to rapidly analyze and visualize large amounts of information on government activities and effectiveness without first having to reengineer the information systems themselves. The necessary attributes are developed in form of external tags, essentially reinventing information, in a more useful form, on the fly.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/take-a-data-gov-approach-to-recovery-gov-using-web-2-0-web-3-0-techniques
 
 
 Take a data.gov approach to recovery.gov using Web 2.0 &amp; Web 3.0 techniques
 
 
 
 Web 2.0 in this sense means using XML to expose data structures, file formats, and services such as feeds. Web 3.0 means going further to expose and link the concepts and relationships found in data structures, file formats, documents, and web pages using semantic web and natural language technologies. 
 RECOVERY.GOV 
 Tracking, making sense, and assessing the stimulus program requires other kinds of data that provided today in recovery.gov. 
 The Obama administration values openness, transparency, collaboration, and connected governance. This is a big topic, especially given the scale of the Federal government (the scope of policy, information, and services that it deals with) and the number of individual citizens, media and social media, private companies, non-profit organizations, localities, states and regional organizations involved in one way or another with the stimulus program. 
 The Recovery.gov site is intended to enable people (citizens, investigative journalists, interest groups, government employees, … anyone) to find out how recovery funds are being spent and what we are getting for their money. Today, information being reported by agencies is limited. It encompasses the program areas authorized, and the funds obligated by the agency. But, not how the money is being used, and what is being accomplished with the funds. 
 So, this is not enough information to enable us to know whether any part of the stimulus program is working. We need to link obligation data from agencies with other sources that will enable us to track who is actually spending the money, where they are spending it, what they are spending it on, how they are spending it, and most importantly, what measurable results we are able to see coming from the monies spent. Where does this data come from? Some will come from Recovery.gov, but much more will come from sources outside of the recovery.gov spreadsheets. So, we need ways to connect information from disparate sources together, if we are going to follow the money from authorized program to use of funds to reported result. 
 Also, to investigate and analyze recovery initiatives, we need data that allows citizens to go deeper than mere surface reports. Creating 200 jobs in a town of 100 people would be suspicious. Creating 200 jobs in a locality that needs 2 million would be insignificant, hence a failure. We need to see recovery programs, spending, and accomplishments in the context of local statistical data and demographics. Sources of local information will be important in assessing the performance of specific projects. Data that enables citizens to gauge whether funds are being wasted or used fraudulently will come from varied public and private sources, e.g., internet social media, news feeds. We need transparency all the way into each specific project, and across its life cycle. 
 The idea is to take a "data.gov approach to recovery.gov" and to implement it using Web 2.0 and Web 3.0 techniques. Web 2.0 in this sense means using XML to expose data structures, file formats, and services such as feeds. Web 3.0 means going further to expose and link the concepts and relationships found in data structures, file formats, documents, and web pages using semantic web and natural language technologies. 
 For additional background on the role of cloud computing, web 2.0 and web 2.0 semantic technologies in implementing Obama administration themes of transparent, open, and collaborative e-governance, see the following presentation: 
 DATA.GOV 
 The Data.gov site is intended to provide a one-stop location where citizens (and their machines) can gain access to public information in a usable form. For data.gov to function, data providers need to expose five key categories on information that make transparency and accessibility operational for both people and machines, namely: 
 1 data set -- can be uploaded or remote 
 2 tagging or metadata about the data giving the structure of the data, provenance, etc. 
 3 definitions of what this metadata means (concepts, relationships, assertions, etc.), also "domain knowledge" explaining how to interpret it. 
 4 API or web services method of accessing the data, preferably REST-ful 
 5 URL where the data can be accessed. 
 The data for data.gov is to be selected and provided by all 25 agencies and 125 programs. The basic idea, in its simplest form, is to expose tables of information using XLM and provisioning data sets to the public using RSS feeds. The back-end concept is under discussion. One view is that agencies should expose data in some standard format that would be ported to some form of data.gov warehouse where it is made available through services. Another concept is that agencies should select from data they already make available on their websites, and provide a web services interface to enable data.gov to crawl the site and harvest the information needed. Trade-offs either way. Personally, I favor making fewer demands on agencies and handling conversion and interpretation issues as part of data.gov's value add. 
 Metadata, Tags &amp; Semantics. 
 To create mash-ups through data.gov or any aggregation vehicle, we have to know something about the data structure and what the data names (or column headings, or stubs, etc.) mean. For example, to answer a recovery.gov query I may need two or more spread sheets containing different information from different sources. I want to build a composite that combines some information from each of them. Sure, I can always rebuild the spreadsheet by hand using Excel. Hand-building is tedious because excel knows nothing about what any of the column heads mean. But, what if I could expose the structure of the spreadsheet so that the computer software could interpret that the column heading was the name of a property, and the cells beneath were instances of this, etc. Then, assuming I've been careful about how I named columns etc. I'd have a semi-automated way to build composite spreadsheets. That's what semantic web technologies give me. 
 Returning to recovery.gov, it gets more complicated if I want to combine (in some way) tables created by different people at different times using different data definitions. Even more complex if I want to map and link content from different spreadsheets, files, documents, web pages, etc. together. In the past we've always done this mapping one-off, by hand, with the results embedded in a particular solutions and not readily re-usable. 
 To map or mash-up different data sources and services, I have a meta data problem to resolve. What did person X mean by data field Y? Is the value presented in spreadsheet #1, for example a measurement of something over some time period, computed in a way that is compatible with other values that are presented in spreadsheet #2? Also, what do I know about the provenance and quality or integrity of the data in either table? When people resolve these questions, they draw on additional information about the data, as well as some knowledge about the domain in which the data is used. Typically, we find definitions written out in documents or on web pages, or we call someone who knows what the data names and data structures mean. 
 What if we would like to have an automated or semi-automated way to speed up and simplify the process of combining or mashing-up data? Then, the computer software needs to access and interpret more information than just the data set plus the data names. That is, if we want the computer to be able to help us to interpret, align, and link information from different sources, then we need to express the semantics of this metadata in a way that is machine computable. 
 What about natural language, and content structures other than tables? In addition, programs that extract information and concepts from natural language (or other sources) can apply the RSS strategy to communicate concepts and instances. This assumes that the classes of information being communicated are known, or otherwise discoverable, by the entity receiving the RSS feed. Typically, the number of classes is restricted, for example, to people, places, organizations, events. Also, when relationships are extracted, then the categories of these are restricted. 
 Linked Data 
 Linked data is powerful idea that has gained a growing following. Linked data calls for expressing structures, tags, and metadata as RDFa / xhtml, which provides a pretty robust way move the metadata around. Semantic web technologies provide a standard way to express both the data (or document, or page) and the meta information about the concepts and relationships of the data set, which can then be processed and transformed externally in various ways not only to change formatting, but also to map, align and harmonize alternative meanings of terms. 
 RSS feeds can communicate the structure of information, together with the content or instances of it. Typically this is applied to tables of data, forms, and simple document structures. Conceivably, it could be extended to schemas of graphics as well. It is the responsibility of the recipient of the RSS feed to know what the tags and structure of information mean. 
 A precursor of current thinking about data.gov was a program that the DC government established to provide RSS feeds for a number of data sets that could be used to create mash-ups and composite services. There was even a contest for putting together interesting mash-ups, widgets etc. that produced a number of cool services, and at zero cost to the government. The data.gov initiative will likely feature contests. 
 Semantic publishing. 
 Semantic publishing means sharing both the human readable, and the machine interpretable forms of information. In addition to tables of structured data, present the data structure and data element definitions and metadata in both human and machine-readable forms. Key ideas here include: 
 · First of all, the concepts of "public information" cover a lot more kinds of content than structured data tables, for example, all of the human-readable content published through government web sites, document collections, published reports, and much, much more. 
 · Second, the "publishing" concept carries with it the implication that this body of information has been subject to editing for understanding by people as well some "quality standard" of consistency, accuracy, and credibility. 
 · Third, the "semantic" aspect of the publishing means that all associated contents -- text, tables, graphics, images, etc. -- come with their structure and metadata expressed digitally (using semantic web, ontology, or other standard) so that any content in the publication can be machine processed as well as read by humans. 
 · Fourth, important government data aggregations and document collections already exist that combine multiple sources, have well formulated methodologies, have checked their facts, are well curated, and supported etc. These make logical building blocks for open public information that is trustworthy, accessible by concepts, and accessible in an internet friendly way. 
While it is always a good idea to start simply and get some early successes, it is also important to look ahead so as not to get boxed in. There is plenty of value from exposing the structure of tables together with the data they contain using RSS. But, this approach will encounter limitations as the data.gov site scales to more and data sets from more sources, as well as sources of higher knowledge content, etc. For data.gov to succeed, we will need to share knowledge about the data and domain in forms that both humans and machines can interpret. This will include incorporating terminology references and techniques for disambiguating the senses of natural language used to identify and define data concepts, provenance, and trust. This requires a form of syndication that is inclusive of ontology (definitions) and natural language understanding.
 
 Meeting the goals of recovery.gov requires methods that accommodate more data formats, sources, concepts and relationships than will be expressed in spreadsheets posted by agencies. The challenge is to make it easier for citizens, journalists, public interest organizations, government personnel and others to find, connect, analyze, the data and sources needed and present results in ways that communicate effectively. This means providing sharable means to expose the structure, concepts and data from many sources. For tables of information and structured forms, etc. this is doable today with either XML or semantic web technologies. However, as the numbers of data sets grows, the complexity of the information represented increases, and (in some cases) the structure of this information evolves, then we need to adopt semantic technology based approaches that can handle the scale, and simplify the combining of information.

 Data-in-common-formats

 Having had a good deal of experience working with D&amp;B both while in government as well as out of government, I would clarify one point. src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/numeric-web-search
 
 
 Numeric web search
 
 Web search is up to now word based. Additionally language independent similarity search of quantifiable objects is desirable. For well defined numeric representation of quantifiable objects a simple data structure called "pattern" is proposed, which contains a feature vector (a sequence of numbers) for representation of the object, and a "pattern name" which is a URI which uniquely identifies the kind of object which is represented by the feature vector. Pattern: Pattern name + feature vector (+ auxilliary data) Patterns with the same pattern name represent the same kind of object. Because the number of possible pattern names is not limited*, infinitely* many different kinds of quantifiable objects can be represented by patterns. (*only physically limited by finite time and energy) So the search terms are not words, but feature vectors in patterns which allow quantification of similarity. Feature vectors of patterns with the same pattern name are directly comparable using a given metric. At this similarities of the original quantifiable objects are mapped to spatial similarities of the feature vectors. So similarity search is possible by calculating distances: Objects are the more similar, the smaller the distance between the feature vectors of the representing patterns is. Due to the multitude of different kinds of quantifiable objects the work for development of efficient pattern resp. feature vector definitions for their representation is open ended. Global task sharing has the greatest potential: According to this suggestion every owner of an internet domain name abc.xyz gets the right to define feature vectors of all patterns with names abc.xyz/* (in well defined location abc.xyz/pat/*). Patterns are machine readable, uniformly comparable and searchable. They allow to search with the same search engine not only for text, but also for an increasing number of well-defined quantifiable objects on the web. This bundling of the search activity into one crawler and web database for all quantifiable objects is much more efficient than building and managing a database and a crawler for every kind of object. Numeric similarity search could be efficiently combined with conventional word based search, templates can be provided by the defining domain for human readable representation of the numbers. Details are described in http://www.orthuber.com/wpa.htm , don't hesitate to ask me further questions. 
 
 We know that quantifiable objects play a central role in daily life. Nevertheless up to now quantifiable objects have in general no well defined globally machine readable and precise representation on the web. The above concept proposes a simple data structure for such representation of quantifiable objects in general which also allows their similarity search. This could induce the "numeric web" as part of the semantic web. After that also numeric data could be systematically collected which can represent reality more precise than language. 
 There is also inevitability if we search an optimal solution. Due to the multitude of different kinds of quantifiable objects we need worldwide task sharing for efficient definition of patterns. The integration of domain names in the pattern name (URI) allows this from the beginning, and also immediate localization of pattern definition and all further information associated with it (e.g. templates for human readable representation in all relevant languages, metric for comparison for similarity search).

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/mortgage-fraud-and-abuse-can-be-stopped
 
 
 Mortgage Fraud and Abuse can be stopped
 
 Today too many mortgage applications are still paper based which makes auditing difficult and allows fraud and abuse to flourish. Title V, SAFE Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 put in place a requirement for loan originators to be trained and licensed but will not be effective if mortgage applications are still paper based and identity numbers (the SAFE Mortgage Licensing Act output) are not tied to electronic signatures that are the legal equivalent of a notarization. 
 By providing an electronic mortgage application submission with the individual loan originator's credentials tied to an HSPD-12 smartcard, HUD, VA, Farm Credit Banks and the GSE's (Government Sponsored Enterprises include Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, and the Federal Home Loan Banks) would then have end to end auditing and compliance capabilities that could be enabled. 
 
 The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 (HERA) and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA), address housing recovery provisions at a macro level through grants and loan programs. However, the confidence of the American people in the mortgage industry, that created loans such as interest only and sub- prime,, is at an all time low. 
 All types of mortgage applications can be made electronic using existing technologies, of which much is already owned. This may be through scanning the paper applications into electronic format or with the entire mortgage application process starting as electronic forms. If the license credentials of each loan originator are identified (in support of SAFE Mortgage Licensing Act) by use of an HSPD-12 smartcard, it would provide a foundation for being able to enforce that if loan originators sell mortgages using loans that are exploitive or deceptive, there would be a legal audit trail used to prosecute the lender and the loan originator. 
 The Sarbanes Oxley Act put in place the enforcement mechanism to require CEOs and CFOs to attest to the validity of their financial filings, so that abuses such as Enron and other high profile corporate scandals will not happen without penalties. An electronic mortgage application submission process, tied to the use of the same digital credentials standards that are used by all Federal workers, would show the American public that there is now a way to enforce and prosecute bad behavior by the mortgage industry. If loan originators write bad mortgages that take advantage of the public, by increasing the likelihood of default, then the loan originator can be identified and stopped. This would be far more than just identifying what lender is selling bad loans. It would identify the individual loan originator that is selling these failing loans. 
 If the public feels that there are new protection measures put in place to reduce and eliminate mortgage fraud and abuse, people will feel safer and will have a greater confidence in banks and lenders that the mortgages will not put them at risk of foreclosure. 
 A solution architecture to achieve this has already been developed and demonstrated to industry and government entities. This has been vetted by of one of the top 10 lenders receiving Stimulus funds, two different State governments that have put in place laws to support this approach, by two large title insurance companies, and through discussions with stakeholders from the Federal entities that oversee the housing and lending industries. This solution is "shovel ready" and a proof of concept with voluntary participants can be implemented in weeks, not months and years.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/what-should-be-reported-and-whats-needed-to-do-so
 
 
 What should be reported and what's needed to do so?
 
 There are a variety of
leading and lagging economic indicators used to measure the health
and well-being of our Nation's economy. The leading indicators such
as the stock market tend to tilt upward long before citizens see
marked improvements to their personal situations. A rising stock
market means nothing to the person who's struggling to make a
mortgage payment or find a job. To banks and business owners this is
a prime indicator that boosts confidence and spurs additional
spending and growth - creating jobs and opportunities for a lot of
citizens. Unemployment and consumer spending are some of the
metrics thought to be lagging indicators. As jobs become available
more folks find work as a result of increased confidence from banks
and businesses. As a result consumer spending usually increases. The
truth about the economy lies somewhere in between the leading and
lagging indicators and can be measured through the identification of
relevant correlations. The focus should be on identification
of data and tools available to measure the effects of spending on the
economy. 
 
 A data warehouse should be
developed that is fast, flexible, robust, scalable AND has a low
total cost of ownership. It should not only enable centralized
collection of data but facilitate robust analytics and reporting
required to ensure openness and transparency. 
 
 Among the data inputs

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/start-with-the-basics
 
 
 Start With The Basics
 
 (1) A project impacting so many aspects of the government is not undertaken without some level of risk. Data will never be perfect. Accept that and get on with it. Adopt an implementation framework that is designed for nimbleness, such as Agile Scrum, to facilitate speed. 
 (2) A good user experience is paramount to success. Consider the many needs of the audience and distill them into a few basic, representative personas around which the site can be designed. View transparency and accountability as a leading "brand" with constituent touch points, of which Recovery .gov is perhaps the most significant in terms of its appeal. 
 (3) Define a simple common vocabulary for constituents, developers, Congress, the Administration, States and Cities. This should include terms like appropriation, obligation, approval, certification and award , among others. Establish a standard corpus of entities and information about them. With the vocabulary and the entities, begin to develop simple data architecture concepts. 
 (4) Choose a basic data format as standard. This doesn't require a significant amount of research as there are many excellent choices available; as long as an open, non-proprietary format is chosen it will be hard to go wrong. 
 (5) An initial dataset is requisite. Get a centralized database up and running quickly and begin processing and standardizing larger volumes of data. It doesn't need to be perfect, and the broad interest from the user community that has already been demonstrated will help to hone the approach. 
 (6) Implement a basic search engine so that spending can be filtered by variables like geography, Federal Supply Codes, and program area. Provide businesses with an easy way to access projects on which they can bid; at a time when businesses are struggling, providing details of Recovery-funded projects serves to create and preserve jobs in local communities. With this, government agencies will get more qualified contractors bidding on contracts and as a result taxpayers will get more value for their dollar - a transparent system that is more efficient. 
 (7) Operate a Recovery Act program assistance center to assist Federal, State and Local agencies with compliance, and assist potential recipients of funds by answering questions about securing grants or contracts. Learnings from this center should be used to inform further development of the site. 
 (8) As the data set grows, provide raw data feeds via APIs to the public at-large. It is not incumbent on the Federal government to create unique and interesting views of the data and, instead, by providing data to developers the public at-large can create engaging user experiences with the underlying data. 
 (9) Look for best practices and pockets of innovation across the public and private sectors which can be adopted. To be successful this can't be onerous on either State, Local and Education entities or the private sector contractors and subcontractors. It is also important to not create an inefficient parallel universe of data and systems. 
 
 At its most fundamental level, this is a data problem not a technology problem. There are some great ideas posted here, many from great vendors with track records of successfully executing on sound strategies. The strategy, however, should start with a basic data set and then layer on these terrific ideas and technologies. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/introduce-a-findability-index
 
 
 Introduce a Findability Index
 
 Industry studies by IT research and trade association firms have concluded there is a persistant challenge for U.S employees to "find" information they need to do their jobs. By some estimates, employees waste 25% of their time "searching" for information to do their job. It is logical to assume this problem is magnified by a factor of 10x in the public sector. 
 
 
 
 
 If Findability and an Index of unstructured and structured data can be improved by a few percentage points then 
 1. Quality service of government would be improved 
 2. Billions Of dollars would be saved. 
 3. The end result would even produce a Green effect from reduced infastructure resulting from optimized IT systems. 
 Note : There is a difference between "searching" and "finding" information. Search Engines are tool that contribute to Findability but they are only one factor.

 Broadly and deeply accessible across all mobile devices
 
 Mobile devices, such as cell phones and portable music players, have varied abilities to interact with outside sources. Cell phones can interact with SMS, Twitter, web sites, calendars, and more. With a little creativity, people have pushed devices further, such as putting <a class="external-link" href="http://encyclopodia.sourceforge.net">Wikipedia on devices such as older iPods</a>. 
 The information from Recovery.gov should be accessible to mobile devices using their native capabilities (SMS, email, CalDAV, SyncML, WWW, WAP, etc.), and should allow for a two-way conversation. But we should also look to the benign hacking community for ideas about stretching the limits of these devices to bring information to citizens. 
 
 Mobile devices are near-ubiquitous and much of the population spends a lot of time with them. They are more common and less expensive than personal computers, and offer a way to reach a large group of people.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/cloud-web-2-0-and-identity-management
 
 
 Cloud, Web 2.0 and Identity Management
 
 Cloud Computing is an attractive way to use software in support of the government's mission. As a topic in IT circles, it certainly gets a lot of ink and with the promise of lowering the cost of ownership of commodity based services such as e-mail it is definitely top of mind with the new administration. The only topic in traditional computing that might get as much ink these days is the hacker/cyber security threat, which targets everyone who uses a computer (Mac, PC, Linux, whatever), or smartphone. Hackers can even affect people who don't use a computer, such as my poor mother, who had her credit card information stolen when a retailer she frequents was hacked. There is also the challenge of identity management that many overlook when investigating Web 2.0 and cloud solutions. 
 
 There's no doubt that consumer services like Facebook and cloud platforms like Amazon/Google/Microsoft Azure are opening exciting new ways for government agencies to get data out to the public. However, as exciting as the evolution of the cloud and web 2.0 has been, the public is still stuck with having to use the ancient method of username and password to secure their personal data in all the various sites where they keep information. As the number of sites that people use has grown, I would bet that the vast majority of people out there are using the same or similar usernames/passwords for many of the sites they access not to mention the ability for somebody to easily impersonate another's identity using a familiar user name. On their own, most people don't set a strong password, and if they use the same one on many sites, they run the risk of having their identity stolen. And that is exactly what has happened to so many people. Apply this to Web 2.0 and the cloud and you really begin to ask the question do I really know who I am following when I'm reading my tweets? 
 
 In professional settings today many public and private organizations use identity access services that require manual submission of attributes like name, e-mail address and phone number to verify pin access to sites after initial authentication by leaving voice mails on a user's phone. Although effective it is difficult to scale these types of solutions due to the manual nature of granting the initial access to a user account. 
 
 There are many people in government who have thought about how to move past the requirement to use username/passwords to secure data DOD has been doing that for several years with their PKI infrastructure. The civil agencies have been working to support HSPD 12, although many of them are not there yet. A government cloud promises open collaboration in and between agencies but also introduces new identity management challenges. Consider for example the challenging task of securely federating government employee identities in a government cloud. Citizen facing applications face even more challenging identity management issues. As the Federal government works to get government data more broadly distributed on the sites people use, like Facebook, Twitter, or on a new cloud computing application, the government should think hard about how to do that in a way that does not force the public to rely on the very thin line of defense that is a username/password. . 
 
 The IT industry has not only been innovating in the web 2.0 or cloud computing space over the past few years. In fact, one of the most consequential developments over the past several years has been the establishment of industry standards like SAML 2.0, WS-* and Info Cards, which provide an open, interoperable and very user friendly way to allow people to log on securely to web sites or applications without the use of usernames or passwords. The general term for this is "claims-based authentication", and the government, at all levels (local, state, federal) has a role to play in enabling this more secure way to access data, especially with what can be very sensitive data (think about your tax return or say your social security information). In fact, given the Obama administration's focus on electronic health records (which is a very good idea), the issue of allowing secure access to this digitized information is only going to become more important in the future. While all this is happening, the bad guys out there, intent on stealing personal data for nefarious ends and are only getting smarter and more successful at stealing usernames and passwords from an unsuspecting public. 
 
 Most people, from all walks of life and across the political spectrum, would say that one of the fundamental missions of government is to keep the people safe. While government generally does a good job of keeping people safe in the physical world (police, militaries, etc…), it hasn't really played a role in keeping people safe in cyberspace, except for punishments for the bad guys after the fact. However, with the advent of things like open identity standards such as claims-based authentication, SAML 2.0 and Info Cards, the government can actually mirror the role they have in establishing a person's identity in the real world (e.g. issuing you a driver's license) with the equivalent in the digital world (issuing you an InfoCard to go along with your driver's license). This doesn't mean that the InfoCard you get from the local DMV would then be the only ID you would need to gain access to secure data, but along with other data from other sources (say your employer affiliation, biometric info, etc), you could create an aggregate set of "claims" with attributes about you from a set of authoritative sources (the DMV, your bank, your employer, the passport office) that you would use to log on to a wide variety of public or government websites. If you think about it, this is really just the same thing as the government issuing you a piece of plastic with your picture so you get the right to drive a big piece of metal on the roads the government builds for you. You need that one piece of plastic to drive, but if you want to get into your office, you need another piece of plastic (your employee ID). Sometimes, you need more than one ID to get in, for example the Pentagon. If the Obama administration championed the use of the open InfoCard standard, it would go a long way towards keeping the public safe on the Internet. 
 
 Check out the following links: 
 
 <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2006/feb06/02-14InfoCards.mspx"> http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2006/feb06/02-14InfoCards.mspx </a> 
 
 <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163626.aspx"> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163626.aspx </a> 
 
 
 Direct Access for Windows and Mobile devices: 
 
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/windows/enterprise/products/directaccess.aspx"> http://www.microsoft.com/windows/enterprise/products/directaccess.aspx </a>
 
 
 As the Web 2.0 and the Cloud play an increasingly vital role in day-to-day citizen and government activities, concerns about online identity theft, fraud and privacy continue to escalate both within the boundaries of the government and thru the governments collaboration with citizens. As the Government begins to investigate how the Cloud can help them meet their demanding transparency and accountability responsibilities it equally important that the data they share and collect is securely managed and accessed. Many industry observers today worry that traditional authentication methods based on account names and passwords have grown inadequate for cloud and online activities. The need for advanced online identity protection has prompted the industry and government to rethink the way digital identity is managed online.

 If the Federal agencies, led by the WH and Congress, only examine the silos of spend by agencies or even groupings of dollars, we limit the opportunity for more effective planning and outcomes-based resource allocations among these silos, assets, and clusters of the economy at the state and regional levels.

 Financial Modeling
 
 It is naive to imagine that we have learnt all there is to learn from the current financial crisis. We understand that trust was abused. Going forward, it would be useful if the financial industry were offered the option for ethical operations set forth within the framework of a financial operating model. It should be possible to come up with a formal model of financial artifacts and their relationships to each other. Properly designed, this model would aid and constrain decisions to be made concerning a financial situation. Computer programs can be developed to work the model. 
 
 The ability to spend money judiciously and expeditiously are important issues in the recovery act. This can effectively be done with human skill and the help of computerized tools. The skill part is irreplaceable, however, a computer program based on a sound financial model would aid in the expeditious decision making for the disbursement of the money. A formalized model would also be able to report on the effectiveness of the spending. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/the-family-menu-a-plan-for-better-health
 
 
 The family menu - a plan for better health
 
 There are a number of helpful programs that encourage people to have a healthy diet and exercise. Unfortunately they are timeconsuming because they require an individual to enter every piece of information. It is important to build on this system because it rewards health and discourages waste. An easier mechanism of data collection would produce better results. There is no need to require anyone to signup, but like my ATM card the benefits are huge. 
 Collaboration between existing business application to purchase food should be enhanced: 
 The weekly family grocery purchase and menu defined online 
 When food is purchased government agencies could provide an overview to a family that discusses their food habbits. Dieticians could become invovled by providing recommendations on healthy adjustments that fit personal taste. Business could reduce consumer traffic by preparing orders in advance for customers to pick up. Since most of our weekly purchases are similar, online applications would provide suggestions based on past purchases that are tweaked before an order is placed. Consumers would be better able to budget their money and focus on less common purchases (another benefit to business). Consumers should also bring their own containers to pick up orders which would reduce packaging costs. Business could compete for the family menu by demonstrating a cost/quality competitive package that targets the family need. Currently groceries tend to profit from favoring businesses that vi for commercially better shelf space. Forcing groceries to compete for the family diet rewards family behavior that is thought out and preplanned. Planned decisions tend to be healthier for the family. Reducing waste or using it productively needs to be an intimate part of the national fabric. A family menu reduces waste because it helps people focus on buying what they use. Groceries should take back their packaging. By keeping records of purchase business can provide easier recycling for returned bottles, plastic and cardboard packaging. This would encourage groceries to prefer industries that package less. 
 The exercise plan 
 
 Exercise time at gyms could easily be tracked for interested participants. Exercise at schools should be tracked too. It would encourage schools to provide a healthy exercise program for kids Injury should be tracked since this should be a factor in identifying individual accommodations in an exercise plan. 
 
 It is important to educate consumers on how to improve their health in a routine non-critical dialog. This is the role that dietitians and health professionals should be providing. Habits tend to change slowly with routine. IT can provide individual analysis that involve human interaction in a way that is impersonal. 
 It is equally important to find ways to reduce waste from packaging geared to sales and impulse spending. By making the consumer aware of their regular purchases their is less waste. Planned spending focuses on use. Prepared orders reduces waste because it saves time and reduces shop lifting. Competition for the family menu reduces waste because groceries are not forced to pander to packaging. 
 The healthy family is the biggest gain of a planned menu. Humanity can plan to be healthy and should be better educated at every step to do that. Planning also encourages budgeting. Consumers can be informed of cost effective alternatives when savings are required or better quality choices when cost is not a concern.

 Too many "Systems of Records"

 2. Consolidate the receiving systesms or go to the source for information. This is after the standardization is done. The sources are the agencies and there should be no translation of information from the source to the several "Systems of records" that we currently have. 
 
 
 One of the challenges for recovery.gov is the fact that there are too many "Systems of records" that the agencies have to submit to FPDS, USA Spending, and several others.
