src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/using-data-analysis-to-provide-responsible-oversight-of-spending
 
 
 Using Data Analysis to provide responsible oversight of spending
 
 Organizations receiving recovery funds should be required to provide proof that they are effectively overseeing and monitoring the way these funds are being spent. 
 For instance, The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Asset Control provides a list of people and organizations that companies should not trade with - i.e organized crime, drug cartels, terrorists, etc. Similarly there are companies that have been debarred, or forbidden to be contracted for future goods and services. Receiving parties should be required to have effective controls in place and proof that they are monitoring these controls to ensure that recovery money is not going towards these organizations. 
 Similarly, effective data analysis techniques should be used to monitor the efficiency of spending - making sure that contract terms are followed, duplicate payments are not made, fair market prices are being charged. 
 Data analysis should also be used to ensure that spending is not subject to fraud. Simple tests can be used to ensure that receiving organizations are not be defrauded by employees or contracting organizations. Numerous data analysis techniques can be used to identify fraudsters by matching addresses, bank accounts for payments, transactions outside of statistical norms, ensuring that goods paid for are received, just to name a few. 
 Excellent guidance on the use of technology for overseeing financial transactions can be found from The Institute of Internal Auditors, (The IIA) and similarly the Association of Certifed Fraud Examiners (ACFE) has a wealth of information on fraud detection and prevention programs. Data analysis technology is key in enabling best practices in these areas and needs to be implemented from the outset to set the tone for recovery spending activities. 
 
 This idea is important to ensure that we get the most out of our recovery funds and allow them to have the intended affect on our economy. It is also key in demonstrating effective management and oversight of taxpayers money, in order to instill a degree of confidence in local leadership in showing the way forward. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/making-recovery-gov-a-website-for-the-american-citizen
 
 
 Making Recovery.gov a Website for the American Citizen
 
 Step 1: Educate the
public that the site is available 
 It is suggested that the
first step in making Recovery.gov a website that the public can use
to "monitor the expenditure and use of recovery funds" is to
first educate the public that the site exists. Use of social
networking sites or periodic RSS feeds from other government agencies
that reference the site are two suggestions for doing this. 
Although this is not a primary focus of this exercise, it should be
mentioned that large scale, continual notification to the public of
the site's existence reinforces the goal of transparency. 
 Step 2: Site
Organization and Data 
 The second step in
improving Recovery.gov is to identify the issues related to the
Recovery Act that Americans are most concerned with and then ensure
that the site is focused on these issues - both from an site
organization view as well as a data view. 
 Currently, when a user
first hits the site they see a display titled "Transforming Federal
Buildings into High Performance Green Buildings", recent news
feeds, announcements, and a timeline at the bottom that has
information until July of this year. All this information is
pertinent, but is it really pertinent to the public citizen? 
 An alternate approach is
to display a list of topics for the user to choose what they are
interested in seeing, such as education, job creation, homeland
security, or tax credits. Upon selection, the user is presented with
a display of all programs that have monies/details associated with
the particular selection, and a geographical representation of where
those monies have been allocated. In the case of tax credits,
details of the credits would be listed. Additional information such
as job creation could also be included. Mouseovers would provide
more detailed information on the given program and/or agency. The
overall goal of the drilldown page is to provide one stop shopping to
the user for all information concerning the selection. 
 What are the questions
that the public is looking for answers to? 
 
 What exactly is
 recovery.gov 
 
 Where is the benefit
 to me by going here? Looking at numbers sent to agencies - I
 don't know what those agencies do, I don't know what those
 programs are. How does that money trickle down to me? 
 
 How do I find out
 about more about the programs initiated through the money (sales tax
 benefits, credits for hiring out of school grads)? 
 
 How are agencies
 working together to solve issues? Query by issue type to see if
 something exists on that issue? 
 
 See state
 comparisons/rollups more readily - which states are getting what
 kind of funding in only one click - not 5 
 
 Timeline shows
 nothing. 
 
 Education, Jobs,
 Healthcare - how is my neighborhood affected, calling my
 congressman 
 
 Simple voting on
 initiatives - public belief in the programs chosen - giving the
 public a voice, see where the concerns are. 
 
 How is this money
 being recouped? Agencies are cutting back on funding, but what
 exactly does that mean - where? 
 
 How is the TARP
 money being allocated and what are the high level aspects of this
 money going to them? 
 
 
 
 The success of
Transparency relies on the ability to quickly convey the answers to
questions germane to the general public. It is not enough to
merely display the total amount of dollars allocated to a particular
agency or state along with a summary of what has been obligated or
disbursed. For this data to provide a level of transparency, more
detailed information must be provided in a manner that is easily
accessible and digestible by an everyday citizen. Additionally,
 relationships between data need to be clearer . 
 The current Recovery.gov
site is heavily text based and presents only surface level
information to the user. Often, it is necessary to navigate through
three web pages or to an entirely new website to view data that is
truly informative to a general public user. Although the site is
fairly clean in nature (no broken links, fonts are consistent, etc.),
there is no ability to easily download or print information, nor is
there is use of Web 2.0 technologies.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/time-geo-and-multimodal-data-viz-on-recovery.gov
 
 
 Time, Geo, and Multimodal Data Viz on Recovery.gov
 
 <a href="http://www.recovery.gov">www.recovery.gov</a> is a great start to actually give life and breadth to the ARRA, its funds, distribution, etc. The website provides some good visualizations of ARRA but not enough. High quality visuals are eye-catching, can be thought-provoking, and ultimately can enable transparency to ARRA. We need more and they need to be more fun, informative, and share-able. 
 We (<a class="external-link" href="http://piim.newschool.edu">The Parsons Institute for Information Mapping</a>) propose extending the usefulness and interactivity of the site's existing information graphics and provide American citizens the ability to visualize the true spend and success of these funds. We need to unite these datasets and visuals into comprehensive and interactive graphics. 
 Leveraging the info. graphics on the <a href="http://www.recovery.gov">www.recovery.gov</a> homepage and incorporating the datasets everyone here is talking about sharing can give some really powerful visualizations - visuals that people will remember, share with friends/colleagues, and help foster the national discussion while supporting transparency. 
 Some examples of work we've done that can be very helpful: 
 The Public Opinion Tool (<a href="http://www.publicopiniontool.org">http://www.publicopiniontool.org</a>) - a web-based tool that educates K-12 students about the electoral process through visualiation and interactivity. 
 The Geospace and Media Tool (<a href="http://piim.newschool.edu/development/geospace-and-media-tool">http://piim.newschool.edu/development/geospace-and-media-tool</a>) - a Section 508/web-based tool for members of US Congress to assess, analyze, and visualize streaming news, demographic, social network, geospatial, and other datasets in a single system. 
 We focus on finding, designing, and engineering innovative visualizations and <a href="http://www.recovery.gov">www.recovery.gov</a> can benefit with a collaboration betwen us and <a class="external-link" href="http://www.esri.com">ESRI</a> and others (e.g. <a class="external-link" href="http://www.visualanalytics.com">Visual Analytics, Inc</a>., IBM [<a class="external-link" href="http://www.many-eyes.com">Many Eyes</a>], etc.). 
 
 Having time-based, geographic-based, and multi-modal (e.g. same data different representation) can help Americans of many backgrounds understand ARRA in their own way. Providing various representations enables communication to a wider audience and helps "speak" to each and every citizen.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/mediation-because-we-have-to
 
 
 Mediation - Because We Have To
 
 Data Mediation - its not actually my idea. Its currently one of the foundational issues facing the federal government and the Deparment of Defense. Data exists in multiple different environments and each environment is a world unto itself, a world with its own language created by the requirements generators, program managers and developers. But the data inside these worlds resides in a jail of the designers making, and, without the correct foundation for release, relies upon point to point mediations (AKA interfaces) with other systems. 
 Mediation must be done through a canonical model based on common vocabularies built from ontologies. These vocabularies are built semantically - there is no one to one matching of terms, rather the definitions of the terms are matched through the relationships that define them. 
 We need to agree upon a defined scope and concept of operations for mediation across the federal government and then apply this through a set of agreed upon standards. 
 The mediation scope 
 We need to agree upon a defined scope and concept of operations for mediation across the federal government and then apply this through a set of agreed upon standards. 
 The mediation scope would include: 
 Semantic mediation 
 Ontological mediation 
 Metadata mediation 
 Protocol adaption 
 Data transformation 
 Security transfer (low side to high side) 
 Relationship of mediation to messaging 
 
 A point to point interface costs an estimated $500,000 over the lifetime of the system. 
 Each change in a mediation requirement or an underlying data element leads to a change in each interface. 
 Without the means to mediate between different vocabularies, the ultimate consumer of data, the public, will not be able to discover useful data and genenate valuable patterns from the data. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/adopt-a-new-world-view-of-transparency-4-steps-to-achieve
 
 
 Adopt a "New World" view of Transparency: 4 Steps to Achieve
 
 Government is truly entering a "new world" - one where citizen engagement matters. That is what transparency is really about. And that is why distributed transparency is important - it leads to effective engagement that truly builds citizen trust.

So how do we achieve distributed or network transparency? In other words how do we dimensionalize government's interactions with citizens, stakeholders and internal agency groups? This is an important question because transparency based on portal based publication, standing alone, will not achieve its intended purpose of building public trust and involvement.

&lt;b>&lt;i>Twitter Themes&lt;/i>&lt;/b>

Let me share a twitter exchange that started with the following two points:

(1) kpkfusion Recovery.gov becomes a single point of failure in a risk assessment. It fails, transparency fails in the public's eyes. #gov2

(2) kpkfusion Transparency advocates should consider distributed network transparency more broadly defined to limit risk of public failure. #gov2

Dan Bevarly (@dbevarly) responded to Sarah Bourne (@sarahebourne) and myself (@kpkfusion) that:

dbevarly: @sarahebourne @kpkfusion Not in agreement. This is insider's (ours) view. Public still does not know what Web transp looks like #gov2

Sarah responded:

sarahebourne: @dbevarly Mismatch btwn what they expected and what is delivered. Problem is potential variations in what is expected. Can be mitigated!

I think that the point that both Dan and Sarah made is important - do citizens really understand what we mean by transparency? Is there an alignment between citizen expectations and what government plans to deliver to achieve "transparency". And what is it?

&lt;b>&lt;i>Distributed transparency&lt;/i>&lt;/b>

As state and local government agencies race to define what is a somewhat abstract notion of transparency, let's ask important questions.

What do citizens expect? Is it another government portal which aggregates volumes of contract data? Or is it something else? Something more meaningful? This is where distributed citizen transparency is most relevant. Citizens will only value that which directly affects them and their quality of life - not an abstract policy debate.

The point is that transparency requires more than publication. It requires dialogue and engagement on a state and local level - in decentralized communications models. What does that mean, and how can government agencies achieve transparency through citizen networks and engagement strategies?

&lt;b>&lt;i>4 steps to "New World" transparency&lt;/i>&lt;/b>

Here are 4 quick steps to consider as we are thinking about how to build network transparency for state and local government.

&lt;i>Step 1: Help gov act "in network". Government should consider evolving from its traditional role of publication to one of interactive sharing.&lt;/i>

As in business, "old world" government organizations have traditionally relied upon a two way exchange - advertising messages, or "portalizing" information. In the "old world" government agencies stand outside of citizen networks and pitch messages into the networks. In the "new world" agencies are being asked to act "in network". In other words agencies are being asked to create value by letting citizens dialogue, debate, and share ideas, based on content added to citizen networks by government agencies.

So the first key in building transparency is to enable localized citizen networks. For instance, when state and local government agencies want to stimulate citizen engagement in transportation, healthcare, education, or other projects will they be most effective with local project involvement sites that support peer to peer communication and perhaps peer based alternative analysis, or a portal with centralized publication of contract information?

&lt;i>Step 2: Enable citizens to share information with each other - building ideas and solution possibilities, in network.&lt;/i>

Businesses are learning that consumers are 9 times more likely to act on the recommendation of a peer (another consumer/citizen) acting "in network" than an business acting out of network, an advertisement. The same can be said of government agencies.

If government actively enables citizens to provide input and to have dialogue with each other, those discussions can lead to the discovery of new solution possibilities and priorities in a way that government acting alone can not. That is the point of transparency. Citizens build trust through dialogue and discussion, not simple availability of information.


&lt;i>Step 3: Government absorbs ideas and new solution possibilities to create efficiencies, save costs,and increase productivity "in network".&lt;/i>

The whole point of listening to citizens is to make things better: (1) To make government work better (2) To make better policy decisions and to (3) identify priorities and make decisions. Getting results builds trust. To build network transparency, government has to not merely accept input and ask citizens to "connect the dots", but to set expectations on how that input will be used - getting to results.

&lt;i>Step 4: As government achieves results "in network" it builds trust with citizens, which in turn accelerates citizen exchange.&lt;/i>

Finally, government has to show citizens how inputs are used. Did their participation matter? That is the point of distributed transparency. As citizens we do things that matter - that make a difference. As government we build trust when citizens make a difference, when we act on their constructive dialogue.

That is the point of acting "in network". That is why distributed transparency is important. That is how government agencies will build meaningful results, and that is how citizen transparency will be a sustainable organizing principle for government. 
 
 The recovery.gov model itself should be examined. At great cost and expense, it misses the point that transparency is only created when government acts "in network" instead of in traditional portal based public communications systems. 
 The model which will truly create transparency would enable state and local government to deploy citizen participation technologies in project based environments. We have built these systems for years, in SaaS models for such projects as Imagine New York, Flight 93 memorial, Statue of Liberty, DoD DAPA, and the Citizen's Healthcare Study. The technology exists today. The current approach being taken by GSA is neither state of the art, nor is it the most cost effective approach. Nor is it ultimately going to meet the intended purpose of building citizen trust. It fails to take advantage of years of experience in building citizen networks and favors using portal based strategies. 
 Constructively, more transparency and citizen involvement can be accomplished at a much lower cost and much more effectively. 
 See http:www.neighborhoodamerica.com Enterprise networks.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/reporting-expenditure-of-construction-funds
 
 
 Reporting Expenditure of Construction Funds
 
 I have an idea that won't require creation of a single additional piece of paper. How about assigning a unique identifying number to each individual project funded in whole or in part by these appropriations. Create a database attaching the identifier with the brief project description already included in the front end of every government construction contract. Then, link the identifier to .pdf copies of the contractor's sworn statement and lien waivers already submitted with each monthly pay request on every government construction job. 
 
 This way, citizens interested in the progress and efficiency of any particular project could quickly drill down to a complete list of every business that was paid any money for labor or materials on the project. Furthermore, neither the bureaucrats nor the contractors on the project would have to write up a single document they are not already required to prepare. As far as I can tell all this information is already required to be public under the freedom of information laws in every state anyway, so no one's toes get stepped on, and no one has to do any extra work. Just run the sworn statements and lien waivers through a scanner every month and e-mail them to Devaney's folks in Washington, D.C. for electronic insertion into the database. Nobody even has to spend money on stamps. Mission accomplished. 
 
 
 Nobody has to create any reports or dopcuments which aren't already needed and used in the payment process, and payment details are immediately accessible to the public. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/use-electronic-forms-to-accelerate-data-collection-cut-costs
 
 
 Use electronic forms to accelerate data collection &amp; cut costs
 
 The Recovery.gov web initiative could accelerate the speed and cut the costs of gathering, integrating and sharing data and information by using modern COTS electronic forms as a component of the solution. Web-enabled forms, designed as standards-based containers that are used to collect information both on and off-line, enable faster, cheaper and more flexible data collection than traditional HTML-based web pages. They can be deployed in days not weeks or months, in formats that enable direct, secure submission of data that is automatically written into target application systems and databases, backed up by builit-in Level 2 signatures where desired at no extra cost to users or the government. They offer the power and flexibility of being distributed in many ways, as components of a web site, as attachments to emails, and as links from and to any location on the web. And because they support robust, built-in data management and business rules capabilities, they make it easier to collect better quality data that government gets when it needs it and with quality that it can rely on . 
 
 Recovery.gov, like the goverment in general, runs on information, but conventional paper and even web 1.0 information collection mechanisms can be expensive and slow to implement. Modern electronic forms that integrate directly within web-based applications and databases cut costs for data providers and recipients, accelerate delivery, and improve results.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/use-a-research-management-solution
 
 
 Use a Research Management Solution 
 
 
 
 Use a Research Management Solution (RMS) to track the due
diligence performed by the government agencies tasked with distributing
stimulus funds. An RMS can systematically capture and organize the unstructured
information required for the analysis of stimulus investments. RMS has been
successfully adopted by money managers all over the globe as a way to create an
open and transparent collaboration among analysts, power better choices for
decision-makers, and create a structured audit trail of analysis. 
 
 
 
 99% of the world's information is unstructured: email
correspondence, documents, spreadsheets, slide decks. While quantitative
analysis is critical, many of the most important decisions are driven by human
discourse - in words not just numbers. Research Management Solutions transform
the cacophony of disparate email inboxes and shared drives into a structured
database shared in real time across global organizations. To provide complete
transparency for the public, the agencies responsible for application of stimulus
funds need to track their internal assessments. These assessments will include
large bodies of correspondence and prose analysis. Research Management
Solutions can transform the potentially chaotic investment research process
into a coherent, organized, and agency-wide effort. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/deploy-a-hybrid-cloud
 
 
 Deploy a Hybrid Cloud
 
 Recovery.gov will more then likely be a very complex interwoven set of enterprise service buses (ESBs) and applications. The chance of all applications playing nicely are probably remote. Of course that is the fun part!! 
 To support such an environment I would normally recommend a hosted private cloud which allows the cloud owners to make the needed alterations without impacting other members of the cloud. Part of that flexibility can be to reach out to a public clould if needed for peak hours of performance A.K.A Hybrid Cloud 
 In a particular use case, some applications may be to complex or sensitive to run on a public cloud. In that case applications that can be migrated could be moved to a public cloud and then those resources can be repurposed for the complex apps that need to stay home. 
 I have to give props to a good friend of mine who thought of this a few weeks back when we were brain storming on cloud use cases. 
 
 The hybrid approach makes sense both from a technology and economic standpoint. It allows for control, flexibility and growth. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/fhwa-mutcd-updates
 
 
 FHWA MUTCD Updates
 
 To update the FHWA MUTCD, Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, in a timely manner. 
 
 It now takes years to correct errors in the FHWA MUTCD and bring traffic control devices, such as signs, traffic line markings, work zone rules, into the 21st century. 
 The current MUTCD has not been updated in years. It was designed for roads that were used 50 years ago. Speeds have increased, signs have (somewhat) improved, but because of the involved system of revision, all changes must be done at one time. 
 Revisions should be done by sections. The legal MUTCD exists only online. Paper copies are not legal and too often outdated. When practitioners rely on improper data, accidents happen. 
 Some rules, such as road markings, are so complicated that the people who actually paint the traffic lines do not understand the original intent of the rules and very often paint incorrect lines. That presents the driver with incorrect information. 
 Safety, and reduced accidents are the issue. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/intelligent-design-modular-farming
 
 
 INTELLIGENT DESIGN MODULAR FARMING
 
 ICT driven small scale modular farming which utilizes ICT to a maximum to expand arable land, improve crop yields and help achieve the Millennium Development Goals to reduce poverty and hunger. 
 See: http://www.paradiso-fp7.eu/contributions.php 
 
 The concept was born out of necessity to meet several demands, first
and foremost the Millennium Development Goals, specifically for
combating poverty and hunger, meet with demand for food and food
security for the ever increasing human population in cities and the FAO
Food for the Cities initiative. 
 
 
It combines new insights in organic waste recycling, waste water
recycling, renewable energy technologies, plastics recycling and
organic composting. 
 
 
It borrows architectural design ideas and concepts on optimizing
surface and three dimensional space and incorporation of vegetation for
decoration and small scale farming into urban design, and builds on the
Japanese concept of modular building design and recent concepts of
vertical farming. 
 
 
Intelligent design in modular farming is based on modern concepts of
precision farming and smart farming, where networked (netted) sensors
are used, GPS, ICT technologies to regulate various (automated)
processes, provide climate control, and remote data access via the
Internet. 
 
 
Intelligent Design Modular Farming is an ICT driven, generalized
concept for agriculture, where in contrast to fixed surface farming,
specific food crops can be grown in mobile or movable modular
environments in a wide range of non-traditional agricultural settings. 
 
 Intelligent Design Modular Farming combines the best of all existng, emergent technologies e.g. linked data and semantic web and smart farming, contributes to creating green jobs and gives content to US commitment to global sustainable development objectives as outlined in the Millennium Development Goals.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/trust-enablement-infrastructure-a-trust-keystone-system
 
 
 Trust Enablement Infrastructure: a Trust Keystone System
 
 You asked: "What do you consider to be the most exciting upcoming technology or
system in the field of managing, aggregating, and visualizing diverse
types of data?" 
 In short, my proposal is a Trust Keystone System . It is a Trust Enablement® infrastructure component that supports all information within the recovery.org ecosystem (analogous to, but not the same as, a generalized eBay infrastructure stripped of the auction and buy-now applications). 
 Trust Enablement® is a proactive, strategic approach to designing business processes that give stakeholders the confidence they need to take consequential actions, such as relying on the validity of information about how the recovery and investment money is being used. 
 
 Trust Enablement® is used by organizations in technologies and business processes to help them achieve their business goals by optimizing the trust of their stakeholders. Trust Enabled(tm) business practices reduce transaction costs and enhance business value in areas as diverse as supply chain management and corporate governance. Trust Enablement® is both a management philosophy and a technology for business best practices. It fills a business practices void by counterbalancing risk management based control mechanisms that preserve trust, with those that develop trust, and thereby provides a complementary, foundational, new management competency. It serves to fundamentally change the leadership mindset from an inside-out to an outside-in orientation. Trust Enablement® has broad applicability, similar to risk management, but its value to business and government is far greater. Whereas risk management is defensively minded and preservation oriented, Trust Enablement® is offensive and growth oriented. For more information about Trust Enablement® visit our web site at <a class="external-link" href="http://TrustEnablement.com">http://TrustEnablement.com</a>. 
 
 
 Although " accountability " and " transparency " are the stated goals of
the President's Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board, I would
argue that the overriding objective is trust (this is supported by
other idea contributors, including IBM). However, accountability and transparency are insufficient conditions for trust , as per our Trust Enablement® Framework. The Trust Enablement® Framework should guide development of a Trust Enablement Infrastructure, an integral part of the larger conceptual model used to guide strategic deployment of the site's functionality. A robust conceptual model allows management to make more complete decisions about which tools and process are needed to support the stated mission of recovery.org. In the absence of a blueprint to guide development the basis for relying on the information will be inconsistent, which will erode
confidence and undermine the effort. Moreover, there is a danger that
over-reliance on transparency and accountability , both critical but
insufficient components of a comprehensive Trust Enablement®
Infrastructure, can cause management to take their eyes off the ball and miss the
overriding objective. We must guard against the tendency of the vast majority to think exclusively about the IT elements for the solution, which can be shortsighted; reinforcing conventional wisdom and the status quo that results in fragmentation. 
 To further support my recommendation, I would direct you to recent polls I conducted that revealed management may not have sufficient competency in enabling trust. See "Insiders' Poll on Trust in Online Social Networks" (<a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/OSN_Trust_Poll-SummaryData.pdf">summary data</a> and <a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/Insiders_Poll_on_Trust_in_OSNs-PreliminaryFindings.pdf">finding</a>) and answers to a recent poll asking "<a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.blogspot.com/2009/04/results-from-stakeholder-trust-poll-of.html">What should business leaders do to improve stakeholder trust?</a>". I also analyzed Canada's Federal Accountability Act (similarly misnamed) to determine the extent to which it contributed to restoring trust in the wake of a high profile government fraud, and found that the term " accountability " may have caused the program to overemphasize protecting over rebuilding trust (see my article "<a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/local/Creating_trust_in_government.pdf">Restoring Trust in Government is more than Cleaning House</a>". The same was to true when I analyzed Sarbanes-Oxley Legislation in my paper "<a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/local/Trust_Enabled_Corporate_Governance.pdf">Trust Enabled Corporate Governance</a>". In support of my position that trust should be an explicit consideration that can and should be addressed systemically, I would direct you to my contributions to the Conference Board of Canada's reports on stakeholder trust at <a class="external-link" href="http://trustenablement.com/index.htm#StakeholderTrust">http://trustenablement.com/index.htm#StakeholderTrust</a>. Finally, beware of vendors promoting myopic solutions as per <a class="external-link" href="http://social.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/EndToEndTrust/thread/60502672-288e-41dc-ab0a-2a65c2d8d6dd">my comments on Microsoft's End-to-End Trust initiative</a>. 
 How can a system intended to develop trust that does not explicitly and competently address trust considerations be expected to have the desired outcome? What's your counter proposal?

 Concerns About Choosing Rural Broadband Awards
 
 The task of choosing rural broadband awards will be daunting. Up to this point in time as an example, RUS has awarded loans &amp; grants that equal nearly the amount that is being asked to be awarded in 2 years. That would infere that to follow the Administration's mandate for dispersing funds, it would behoove the USDA &amp; NTIA to grant LARGE project awards to more easily utilize manpower to evaluate award performance that has to pass in front of Congress for reviews. The obvious bias will be towards larger companies and that will not necessarily give rural areas the coverage that they desperately need. Smaller companies with appropriate business plans will be more inclined and more familiar with covering Rural America in high-speed broadband. If the major companies had business plans to cover rural areas, they would have already accomplished the task. 
 
 Rural America will be better served by dispersing a majority of the Simulus Funds to smaller, rural Companies. RUS will have to significantly change their review and acceptance process in order to get the funds out where they are needed. Let's not just look at what they have awarded, also review how much money was actually dispersed. Change the criteria to 10% instead of 20% for a business-match requirement.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/tracking-grants-for-energy-efficiency-and-their-long-term-benefits
 
 
 Tracking Grants for Energy Efficiency and their long-term benefits
 
 IDEA: For each grant recipient, grant funds' disposal data and energy efficiency achievement data must be available in a single database for public awareness and analysis. 
 Huge amounts of economic stimulus dollars are directed towards energy efficiency in public buildings and in schools. Four compliance goals for this grant money ought to be: (1) it was spent quickly to create jobs, (2) it was spent wisely on RIGHT retrofits, (3) that energy efficiency actually improved in each building and was sustained, and (4) reporting the compliance status ought to be automatic, i.e., should not be costly, time or labor effort intensive. 
 Transparency surrounding the grant money must include not just who got how much money when but also the results attained and maintained through the uses of the money. 
 Money should be accounted for in nationally standardized GL codes and budget status categories. Invoices covering all spending must be available as scanned images on-line (or equivalent EDI transactions) showing the accounting trail in terms of amounts, recipients, dates, and purposes. 
 Energy Efficiency results should be accounted for starting with baselines of energy usage, costs, and Energy Star Performance Rating benchmarks. Use of environmental sensors and sub meters can de-construct the energy use at process level within buildings at hourly or shorter intervals. Retrofit decisions can be then made wisely. It is wise to "Read The Problem" before starting the spending on solutions. 
 Having collected the baseline for each building in terms of its energy use, spend, and Energy Star Performance Rating benchmarks, it is now possible to track these results month by month in future years to see if Energy Efficiency (measured as Energy Star Performance Ratings) actually improved through the retrofits installed and was sustained over the years. 
 TeleBright's ManageRight database platform currently provides the foregoing capabilities today and can be scaled. All data can be made publicly searchable with analytical reporting to enable FULL transparency. 
 Regardless of actual IT solution deployed, (1) the total spending, and (2) Energy Star energy efficiency ratings data for all buildings, for all grant recipients must become public; and become available for search and analysis by the public. 
 
 
 This idea is good because the common sense objectives behind the grant are met at very low cost and effort. It holds grant recipients accountable for spending the grant money quickly, wisely, and enables them to report (easily) on the residual energy efficiency improvements results achieved and sustained long after the original grant money got spent.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/create-a-standard-a-z-reference-site-wiki-for-health-related-content
 
 
 Create a standard A-Z reference site/wiki for health-related content
 
 Create a single national wiki for health conditions, treatments and procedures that includes the following areas (as examples): overview, symptoms, causes, diagnostic criteria, treatment options, self-help options, carer advice, personal stories, recent advances, complications, prevention, questions to ask your doctor, references 
 
 The content should be structured so as to allow for easy syndication and service access (i.e. extract any part of the content in XML format for use elsewhere) 
 
 The content should be made freely available to all users 
 
Trusted Content areas should be approved by a volunteer-based 
 medical committee and allow for a mix of clinically trusted content and more personal content...for example, the only people who would be able to edit the description of treatment for diabetes would be authorized clinicians. Changes to this content would be reviewed by an appropriate panel before publication. These authors and panels would be expected to be volunteers. However, patients/carers/citizens could add in personal stories discussing their experiences in alternate treatments. This content would be reviewed as well for appropriateness but would not need to be proven as clinically sound. 
 
 Trusted Content can be shared with international parties as well as national organizations 
 
 Areas should be allowed for the public to add in (moderated) content about their experiences and stories; this content should be clear in that it is not clinically authorized 
 
 Links should be made available to trusted knowledge partners for particular areas 
 
See www.nhs.net for an example of how the UK implemented this idea. (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Pages/bodymap.aspx">http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Pages/bodymap.aspx)</a>
 
 
 The government's investment would be to set-up the initial site, collect and review the content and then oversee the ongoing content authorization process to ensure that the content is appropriate for public consumption. The public would be responsible for on-going content creation and one can imagine parterships with leading national organizations such as the NIH, the Mayo Clinic or international partners such as England's National Health Service. 
 
 The internet is a wonderful tool for people to get more informed and engaged in their health but traditional search engines can lead to information that is inaccurate, incomplete or even malicious. 
 Furthermore, there is a lot of time and money being invested in re-creating this content. This basic content should be a national resource that people can work off of to provide better treatment. There should be one trusted place that our citizens can go to to get the information they need that will lead to better health in general (which of course will help in containing overall health costs.) 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/near-real-time-notifications-and-transactions
 
 
 Near real time notifications and transactions
 
 Put an emphasis on data being available quickly - not months after the fact. Use Common Alerting Protocol (CAP), a standard developed in California, and managed by both OASIS and NIEM that allows rapid dissemination of information - imagine torndao warnings that came out 3 weeks after the fact - not useful. 
 CAP allows for geo-locating the inforamtion, and is far more simple than many other standards like XBRL (which are very useful for more in depth, detailed tracking of information and should be use aggressively). 
 CAP can enable a map of alerts that is easy to consume, yet leverages all the data out of more complex formats. NOAA, USGS, FEMA and others have all adopted CAP, and it would be a very good step to see how many jobs were reported daily, how many new contracts, and more in a geospatial format. 
 
 Getting the stimulus out there is key to getting job creation going, and speed of reporting will help hold the various issuers of the stimulus money accountable, and raise the transparency level - if data is reported rapidly, there is much more time for others to partner with those recipients.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/design-design-design
 
 
 Design,Design, Design
 
 Assemble an experienced Design Team.

 What is surprising to me is that this dialogue is completely focused on "How". This is surprising because the "What" is not clear. To actually get to the destination safely, on time and on budget we'll need to know more about what is between us and the destination.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/make-room-for-communicating-impact-not-just-tracking-expenditures
 
 
 Make room for communicating IMPACT, not just tracking expenditures.
 
 There are some terrific ideas here. Leaving the outright sales pitches aside, much considered insight is to be found in both the ideas and the comments sections. But nearly all of the focus is on the tracking of expenditures and not on their intended impact. I find this troubling. While the tracking of expenditures is necessary and should be transparent (and is the jist of the question that was asked), it drives toward a "getting my fair share" perspective (evidenced by a number of comments), and away from the broader questions about whether and how the reinvestment leads to real recovery (and transformation), not just rescue. Moreover, many current performance measure are already too output focused (e.g., number of people served). I fear we will wind up with a long list of expenditures ranging from short-term employment to the purchase of paperclips, but not a real understanding of whether and how any of it made a difference. I would love to see a <a class="external-link" href="http://manyeyes.alphaworks.ibm.com/manyeyes/visualizations/743467d0ec2b11dd93ac000255111976/comments/f77e4a02f6cb11ddbf8f000255111976">manyeyes/propublica</a>-style version of impact, using predictive multipliers in combination with survey data and even anecdotal content (I know it's possible to contribute anecdotes right now, but we could turn a few into case studies). I could also imagine a site/service that did time series - investment against economic activity. I understand that the level of complexity we are talking about here boggles the mind - multiple data systems with different levels of proprietary content and multiple output formats tracking inapprorpriate targets. Still, we need try to track impact - even if we don't get it right, we need to do it. And we need to do it on recovery.gov, or the site will simple function as an audit. Not very interesting. Does not inspire confidence. 
 Brookings warns of a similar danger <a class="external-link" href="http://www.brookings.edu/reports/2009/0330_american_recovery_reinvestment_act.aspx">here. </a> 
 
 
 We're already spending. We need to know where it goes, yes. But we also need to know whether it made a difference.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/middleware-soa-rest-framework-for-data
 
 
 Middleware SOA REST Framework for Data
 
 Implement a middleware framework that enables information
consumers to gain easy access to a variety of information sources under common
and standardized formats. By placing a
re-usable SOA (Services Oriented Architecture) framework on top of traditional
relational data, flat files, and or
hierarchically structures, the complexities of data silos and multiple formats
are eliminated. By layering a framework between
data sources and the web, information seekers can create easily create web
accessible interfaces that mix and match information across and within information
domains. Using this approach and with
minimal effort , data can be applied to web 2.0 and "Mash-up" applications, including automatic delivery of subscribed
 feeds in formats such as XML, RSS, Atom, thus
increasing Recovery.Gov's ability to get 
the right information out to the right constituents using a low cost and highly efficient web delivery model. 
 
 
 
 Recovery.Gov will need to collect, maintain and deliver large
amounts of data and transform this data into consumable and actionable
information. This can be a very difficult
and expensive task, since most organizations have data in a variety of formats
and access methods. The importance of this idea is linked to driving a
re-usable web services information delivery model. Through information architecture patterns
such as REST "Representational State Transfer" Recovery.Gov's information could
be made accessible to the web, and support read once, and publish many model.
 This idea will help Recovery.Gov provide
low cost capabilities that offer quick access to data including turning it into
information streams that can be easily added to web sites across the entire World
Wide Web. Our team has implemented this
type of framework and it provides great business value and information access
across our many business domains. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/data-collection-extend-whats-already-available
 
 
 Data Collection - Extend what's already available
 
 We have worked with the procurement and grants communities within the federal government for over 20 years providing procurement and grants management systems. There are many systems that collect this
information within the government (e.g., budget, procurement, grants,
financial) and then feed the information to the centralized government systems
(e.g., FPDS-NG, USASpending.gov, FAADS). The issue is that the information gets
watered down as it passes through the systems. The source systems have a superset of the information that the centralized systems require. Additionally, each new centralized system comes with its own XML
schema for the data that it tracks. This results in many "single-purpose"
interfaces to support the various types of reporting. The Integrated
Acquisition Environment (IAE) took steps to address this in 2005 with the
development of the "Standard Transactions Dictionary". The Department of Defense has taken it a step further in their procurement data standards but this has a DoD focus and does not cover the grants community.

If we could build on these standards, however, and add the additional elements for
the grants and financial communities then we could have a complete picture in
one XML schema of any government procurement or grant spend. The vast majority of this information is already captured for transparency in the pre-award process. The model could easily be extended to include the
recipient reporting as well. 
 
 Imagine having the ability to slice and dice the data in any direction for the purposes of your specific analytic need without having to request the data in yet another format. This is achievable if we include
the knowledgeable groups within government as well as the experienced contractors that have been living this for many years. 
 
 The key to success will be to include the groups both inside government and the partners to government who have the best insights into the unique procurement and grants environments and the data that is already available for distribution. 
 
This issue is very important to us so please let us know how we can contribute!
 
 
 
 This is a great forum with lots of ideas (and more continually coming in) for getting the data out to the public; but, in conjunction with thinking about the distribution of the data, we should also be thinking about the collection, validation and accessibility of the source data. The success of any data distribution relies on its data sources. If we don't include that in the dialogue, then we're ignoring the backbone of the infrastructure. 

This is not just an issue for Recovery.gov -- this is our opportunity to "begin with the end in mind" and put into motion the right tools for government transparency to continue and expand even after the economy has recovered!

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/public-research-infrastructure-built-on-open-access-repositories
 
 
 Public Research Infrastructure built on Open Access Repositories
 
 The idea entails the creation of a national public infrastructure for general research built on ICT, which will enhance the currently in place online networks of repositories, such as libraries, applied and pure research, academic publications, general technical information, public federal information databases. 
 Taken the idea of open access to the next level by applying the Berlin Declaration: 
 http://oa.mpg.de/openaccess-berlin/berlindeclaration.html 
 
 
 Currently most of the information in the USA is distributed among varying sources of information, with different standards for access, normalized standards for storage and retrieval and loosely defined guidelines for inter-connectivity. 
 Using the principles and technologies of open access publishing, open source software platforms, and technologies for linked data and in a more specialized from semantic web technologies (e.g. DublinCore Metadata Initiative), a new web of public open data for research can be woven. 
 This web of date will harness the full potential of the internet, the academia, libraries, public data in federal agencies, research data and utilize the power of open source software and platforms to further decision-making and engagement of all stakeholders in all processes relevant to the path of recovery at all conceivable levels, at the same time promoting transparency and accountability. 
 President Obama stressed the need to borrow good ideas from others, we suggest borrowing from the European Union, from the Digital Repository Infrastructure Vision for European Research (DRIVER): 
 http://www.driver-support.eu/index.html

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/comparative-analysis-tools-needed-to-look-horizontally-across-projects
 
 
 Comparative analysis tools needed to look horizontally across projects
 
 There will be many ways to slice and dice the data collected and present it in meaningful ways. 
 This idea combines a proven approach with a new twist specifically focused on reporting and analyzing data related to ARRA spending and projects. The idea looks at how comparative data approaches can be used to analyze how money is spent and the impact it has made. Based on the required data elements and the data reported, the comparative analysis would focus on outcomes. For example project dollars spent (vs. project dollars budgeted), project timeline actual (vs. project timeline budgeted), jobs created, nature of project, and location of project (state, county, and municipality). Through simple selection of criteria, oversight organizations, accountable officials, and citizens could view results and compare projects - one against the other to see which are or have performed effectively and those that have not. In addition, you can complete trend analysis across broader categories. 
 This approach has been used effectively at HHS to assist patients access and evaluate their providers (hospitals) and the provider outcomes. <a href="http://www.hospitalcompare.hhs.gov/"> www.HospitalCompare.HHS.gov </a> 
 The primary purpose of the Hospital Compare tool is to provide information about the quality of care in hospitals that have volunteered to report their data for five clinical conditions. The tool also provides users with information regarding inpatient hospital payment information and number of Medicare patients treated for certain illnesses. The tool provides users with the ability to search for hospitals by state, county, city, ZIP code or hospital name and compare hospitals against each other based on the quality of care they provide. 
 This public reporting of hospital quality information has been effective in increasing public awareness and understanding health care quality, as well as reform quality improvement activities in hospitals. It also gives health care providers information they can use to improve their quality of care, educate patients, and promote public's ability to make informed decisions when choosing hospital care. The same would be true for reporting recovery spending. 
 
 Ongoing analysis would show appropriate and effective use of funds and identify those (projects, states, counties, municipalities) requiring additional oversight or re-alignment of recovery dollars.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/data-revenue-sharing

 The idea is to establish

 Risk and Fraud Analysis
 
 The Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board is considering all options for open-source research, fund tracking, and predictive analysis tools. Can you please provide solution ideas for the following: 
 Open-Source Research - Currently, the private sector is using open-source information as a cornerstone of its risk-based strategies (e.g., only pulling from public databases, news sources, internet sites, etc.). The RATB should employ these tools to allow for transparency among all recipients. 
 Funds Tracking - Never before has there been such a huge data set (Recovery Funds) so conspicuously labeled for accountability. Tools that will help the public see the funding all the way down to the final user would be a great addition for transparency. 
 Predictive Analytics - We need to do what we can to prevent fraud before it happens . There are very comprehensive tools that focus on complex data streams using visualization for risk-based targeting of potential fraud. These tools are commonly used among the credit card, banking and credit bureau industries. 
 
 We are looking for the best solutions available to provide the public the best open and transparent oversight of Recovery Act funds. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/the-success-of-recovery-depends-upon-collaboration
 
 
 The Success Of Recovery Depends Upon Collaboration
 
 
 
 The
unprecedented challenge of recovery and its intergovernmental nature requires an unprecedented shift in past patterns of behavior at all levels of
government. To find the new patterns
that will succeed, every one of the traditional concerns of the Federal government needs to
be turned on its head: 
 Instead of the development of the Recovery program all by itself, the Federal government should look to state/local
governments for assistance in developing the regulations, reporting/data
formats, procedures and even auditing techniques for the recovery program. This
would almost be something like Wikipedia for the regulations/procedures
relating to each part of the program, with a group of "volunteers" from all
levels of government helping to edit and moderate all of these
contributions. The Federal government
might even find that state/local governments will come up with more precise and
tougher regulations than they would dare ask on their own. Most members of
the public realize that the data on the Internet, while voluminous, is not
always 100% accurate when first published. 
While the public may not fully "understand the context" of the recovery program
(as one Federal official put it), they do understand the context of the
Internet - that it is a dynamic and participative medium. So as quickly as possible, not at some time
in the future, the site should be open for public input, photos of what citizens
see as recovery successes and failures, etc. When final
regulations/procedures are issued, there are bound to be additional questions.
So recovery.gov needs to have a place where state/local officials can post
questions - and receive answers - with regard to each provision. This would be
shared with the whole community of state/local officials, so Federal agencies
don't need to answer the same questions over and over again, and also that
state/local agencies work off of a common understanding of the answers. As part of their
own responsibility to their constituents, state and local governments will want
to maintain their own databases of recovery projects. Recognizing this fact,
but also the need for the recovery.gov to be a central portal for this
information, the IT staffs of the Federal, state and local governments should
develop a standard for the exchange of this information and reporting about
recovery projects. There have been some previous examples of such
intergovernmental cooperation in developing data exchange standards, such as
criminal justice data sharing. XML and
similar Internet standards are common outside of the government and made
mashups so widespread on the web. There are just not enough inspectors to ensure that money will not be
wasted. Instead, the state/local
governments themselves as well as the general public should be used as the
Federal government's eyes and ears. A
state/local agency may not publish information about its own waste, but if it
feels it is playing by the rules, it might report some other government's wasteful
use of recovery funds. And so will the
public. But the web also offers the
accused a chance to respond. The whole
collaborative process can take on valuable aspects of self-policing. While it is not perfect, this may well
identify more problems than the likely small corps of Federal inspectors could
uncover alone. Finally, there is a difference between abuse and mediocrity. So the Recovery program on the web should also
encourage the sharing of best
practices. This would accelerate the
progress of the economic recovery by quickly propagating the most effective
approaches around the country. 
 The answer is not a big, lengthy Federal IT system
that is intended to ensure no mistake ever happens. That utopian solution will likely arrive
after the recovery is over. Instead,
Internet-based collaboration among all the governments and involved citizens -
quick, inclusive, perhaps not ensured of perfection at the start - will be the
key to a successful recovery program. 
 
 
 
 Going
beyond the question as to how best to use the Internet for reporting and the
like, to add to President's challenge, in the "real world", the implementation
of the recovery program depends upon the work of thousands of state and local
governmental agencies. So if it is to
succeed, the Obama administration needs to facilitate cooperation and
collaboration among Federal, state and local agencies in the planning,
monitoring and even the administration of ARRA. 
 Fortunately,
the shared common communications network - the Internet - between all of these
governments and the collaborative technology that operates on top of that
network make it possible for the recovery program to work in a way that was not
possible in the past. This has the potential to optimize both the reporting and data side of the recovery program, as well as its implementation. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/data-visualization-portability
 
 
 Data Visualization Portability
 
 Data visualizations are the combination of three things - the underlying data, the visual tool or graphic used to portray it, and the document or Web site in which it is ensconced. While sometimes this is desirable, for government transparency and information sharing purposes, it severely limits the ability of citizens, interest groups, journalists, and others to understand and/or re-interpret information. 
 Instead, tools and software should be used that loosely bind information to the visualization being used and the media being used to convey it. 
 
 In an information economy, we are also increasingly driven by an information-managed government - from the rules about public disclosure to the transparency of financial transactions entered into by private enterprises. When the people, the press, and the other branches of government cannot extract the data needed to understand their world, that information will in some cases be considered "biased" or tainted simply because it is not easily discernable. 
 Government is not transparent until its data is. Data is not transparent until it can be used and re-used at the discretion of its consumer - not just its producer. 
 
 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/added-incentives-for-innovation-and-sustained-benefits
 
 
 Added incentives for Innovation and Sustained Benefits
 
 In my stimulus dealings with various Federal, State, and Local Government leaders there appears to be 2 distinct schools of thought emerging. On the one hand are those agencies who view ARRA as a short term tactical fix to numerous funding challenges associated with significant budget deficits. On the other hand is the thinking which looks to use stimulus dollars as the vehicle to transform existing programs to provide an even greater level of public service to citizens, businesses and constituents alike. 
 Can we provide an additional financial incentive to those States who clearly demonstrate such creative thinking and are laying a strategic infrastructure for future interactions between State and Federal Government agencies? 
 
 Although the ARRA has a prescribed timeline with defined start and finish points, the true value of this program will be measured by the results it drives in how government serves each of us. Incenting a more strategic application of funds will drive the behavior and outcomes we all desire.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/consolidate-data-collection-processes-enhance-content-functionality-vis
 
 
 Consolidate data collection processes; enhance content, functionality &amp; vis
 
 View the recovery.gov effort as not just a taxpayer accountability function but as a hands-on decision support tool for government project managers; an accounting and budgeting tool for government financial managers; a research tool for individuals, businesses, organizations and agencies seeking funds; a policy-making tool for members of Congress. Integrate recovery.gov data collection and dissemination with usaspending.gov as called for in Peter Orszag's OMB Memo M-09-15. The key to successful data collection will be the "key" of each data record. Unless data from multiple sources contains properly formatted indexed keys, the data will remain in separate un-relatable data stores and the analysis that all users desire will be impossible. The key to being able to link expenditure data with the obligation data is having common fields as keys in each record. The expenditure records must contain the agencyid, piid, mod in the same format etc. or we'll never be able to match everything up. The FAADS system needs a record ID to link to expenditures. The TAS/program source, which seems to be where the government is heading, might not be sufficient to tie these transactions together. Include DUNS keys to all vendor and recipient records. Add POP location keys and zip codes to all places. Standardize recovery.gov data fields as closely as possible with usaspending.gov and FPDS-NG data. Report every transaction, not just consolidated transactions. $750 billion is about 1.5 years' worth of contract data or half a year's worth of contract and grant data combined. Quite manageable and scalable with properly designed data collection and reporting systems like <a href="http://www.usaspending.org/"> www.usaspending.org </a>. Institute strict validation routines on reported data that insure the TAS will be reported in every transaction record, not just in recovery records. Create a separate field for the TAS - keep the FPDS Description of Requirement field for program descriptions. Flag all recovery transactions separately in a logical field. Include full program source/TAS codes for every recovery obligation and expenditure record to facilitate reconciliation with other agency budget, obligation and expenditure records. Fulfill terms of FFATA -- feed expenditure data from agency core financial systems weekly to an intermediate data store where usaspending.gov &amp; recovery.gov obligations, and budget data can be reconciled with expenditures. To the extent feasible require agencies to use contract writing systems certified compliant with FPDS-NG v. 1.3. Institute sub-award reporting from award recipients down to the nth tier with enough links to tie directly to the usaspending.gov and recovery.gov data. Have recipients report through a system like Orion Microsystems or an enhanced <a href="http://www.esrs.gov/"> www.esrs.gov </a> , provide weekly feeds of core data fields from this system to an intermediate data store for reconciliation with obligation and budget records. Reserve final recipient payments until their data is fully reported and reconciled. Eliminate redundant grant data processing functions - standardize on either FAADS and FAADS+. Improve quality and timeliness of grant, assistance &amp; loan reporting. 
 
 Will lead to fuller taxpayer accountability; better program management, more accurate account reconciliation. Increased visibility into project execution will improve our understanding of what has worked, which projects should be renewed, which projects should be shut down. Save cost, reduce errors &amp; confusion by eliminating redundant data processing &amp; dissemination efforts. Automated expenditure data feeds from core accounting systems will reduce oversight intrusiveness and simultaneously enhance management capabilities. Leverages a sophisticated decision support &amp; market research tool out of the same investment in transparency and taxpayer accountability. Fulfills requirements of FFATA. No time to lose -- many elements already exist off the shelf &amp; are ready to go.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/broaden-continue-the-discussion
 
 
 Broaden &amp; continue the discussion
 
 This dialog is a great idea, as are the willingness to open up the discussion for broad access, the presumed commitment to devote resources to identifying and following up on better ideas with clear benefit, and the use of web tools for making it happen. 
 There is a continuing need for this collaboration, not only for the Recovery program, but across the federal government as a whole, including especially the government's would-be program for managing information and technology across the federal enterprise. 
 Our new federal CIO should take the initiative to adopt this approach as a strategy for creating an effective government-wide program, broaden the dialog, continue the discussion for at least the next six months, and explicitly find and devote resources monitoring the dialog to find and follow up on ideas with important benefits for the government that in many cases will actually pay for themselves. 
 
 Federal programs could produce far better results, on a much more cost-effective and efficient basis, if they better leveraged information and technology. And way too many players, including stovepiped government activities and way-too-comfortable contractors, perpetuate this wasteful status quo. An ongoing collaborative effort of this kind, coupled with careful and focused follow-up by government, could bring the real change we need. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/what-should-be-reported-and-whats-needed-to-do-so-1
 
 
 What should be reported and what's needed to do so?
 
 There are a variety of
leading and lagging economic indicators used to measure the health
and well-being of our Nation's economy. The leading indicators such
as the stock market tend to tilt upward long before citizens see
marked improvements to their personal situations. A rising stock
market means nothing to the person who's struggling to make a
mortgage payment or find a job. To banks and business owners this is
a prime indicator that boosts confidence and spurs additional
spending and growth - creating jobs and opportunities for a lot of
citizens. Unemployment and consumer spending are some of the
metrics thought to be lagging indicators. As jobs become available
more folks find work as a result of increased confidence from banks
and businesses. As a result consumer spending usually increases. The
truth about the economy lies somewhere in between the leading and
lagging indicators and can be measured through the identification of
relevant correlations. The focus should be on identification
of data and tools available to measure the effects of spending on the
economy. 
 
 A data warehouse should be
developed that is fast, flexible, robust, scalable AND has a low
total cost of ownership. It should not only enable centralized
collection of data but facilitate robust analytics and reporting
required to ensure openness and transparency. 
 
 Among the data inputs
should include: 
 ARRA allocations and
expenditures at a fine grained level, by program, industry, region,
etc Mash-ups of publicly
available data [Unemployment, consumer spending, foreclosure rates,
housing starts, other demographic information that can be directly
correlated to funds spent on specific programs or locales] 
 
 
 Among the data outputs
should include: 
 Visualizations to provide
intuitive understanding of the economic situations and corresponding
indicators Ad-hoc capabilities to run
predictive models and analysis to understand how making changes to $$
allocations for various programs or projects may impact regions
differently and tune these models and allocations as baseline data
becomes available Web 2.0 and feeds to
enable citizen created-mashups 
<a class="external-link" href="http://www.johnstonmclamb.com/Solutions/recoveryAct2009.aspx">http://www.johnstonmclamb.com/Solutions/recoveryAct2009.aspx</a>
 
 
 
 Data Warehousing is an
important component of the solution. Tracking the funds and spending
is a major component of the solution but it means nothing without an
understanding of the effects of dollars spent. The key is creating
the ability to measure tangible results associated with funds spent,
which means there is a need to correlate monies spent spent with
results. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/business-intelligence
 
 
 Business Intelligence
 
 IDEA: Standardization of design/implementation of Business Intelligence/Data Warehousing Systems along with Storage Technology/Online Transaction Processing (OLTP) Technology Refresh Incorporation 
 The need for Business Intelligence/Data Warehousing. In today's highly uncertain and extremely competitive world, the timeliness of an enterprise's information, as well as the integrity of such data from which critical information is derived, can mean the difference between profit and loss or even an enterprise's survival. In sales analyses and marketing trends, credit card churn analysis , Insurance fraud analysis , call record analysis (landline and cellular call record analysis) , logistics management and other critical needs, the call for designing and implementing systems robust and scalable to withstand the processing of vast amounts of data and to do analyses in real time are vital. Therefore, the idea I have to 1.) Standardize on a methodology that includes multiple steps: business case justification, enterprise evaluation (architecture and data stores), Project Planning (based on standardized PMBOK principles), complete requirements definition, data analysis, meta data repository design, ETL design, data mining and phased deployment; 2.) Ensure storage technology and consequent state-of-the-art robust transaction processing are routinely incorporated into the designs and implementations of such systems. There is a constant improvement in the size of storage, now routinely in the terabyte arena - the needs exist constantly to improve on the software's design to process transactions quickly in the newly evolved vast relational database structures. 
 
 
 In today's highly uncertain and extremely competitive world, the timeliness of an enterprise's information, as well as the integrity of such data from which critical information is derived, can mean the difference between profit and loss or even an enterprise's survival.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/maximizing-competition-oversight-and-accountability-for-arra-funds
 
 
 Maximizing Competition, Oversight, and Accountability for ARRA Funds
 
 State departments of transportation are ultimately responsible for the proper oversight of federal funds passing to local governments for road construction projects. Some do a good job in their oversight, but most have their own problems to deal with and don't give this area the proper attention required. There are several systems that have been developed in the last few years that focus on the local government market. For example, AASHTO's contractor (Info Tech) has developed web-based electronic systems comparable to those deployed in the state DOTs that are available as hosted applications (SaaS) and at price points affordable by even the smallest agencies. Its' Appia ® software seamlessly interfaces with the state's electronic bidding system, so that local bidding opportunities get the widest possible distribution, leveling the playing field and resulting in lower prices for the agency. It also includes a pre-award analysis function that helps spot collusive behavior. Since it's web-based, its' extensive project reports are readily available to the state DOT for transmittal to FHWA and for meeting ARRA reporting requirements. State DOTs should be strongly encouraged to maximize this opportunity to use a small amount of their Stimulus dollars to fund their local government oversight programs. 
 
 The Office of Management and Budget's guidance on ARRA includes requirements "to meet crucial accountability objectives," such as obtaining maximum practicable competition, maximizing opportunities for small businesses to compete for contracts, ensuring timely award and expenditure of dollars, minimizing cost overruns and improper payments and collecting contractor performance evaluations. Key elements of the program are Discipline - creating efficient, repeatable processes; Transparency - providing equal access to all competitors; and Accountability - spending funds wisely and achieving the goal of putting people back to work as quickly as possible. The state departments of transportation picture is 'bright' because their American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) developed systems are in place and up to date in the vast majority of these agencies. Their electronic bidding system (Bid Express) maximizes competition and provides opportunities for minority contractors, their Trns*port construction management system provides a complete electronic audit trail of the expenditure of funds, and their collusion detection system is capable of identifying unscrupulous contractors. 
 However, the local government agency picture is 'not so bright.' Construction processes are primarily paper-based and weaknesses are apparent in cost estimation (lack of discipline), contractor change orders &amp; timely payments, and personnel and equipment tracking, making audits and accountability extremely difficult. In fact, FHWA has made Local Program Administration its' number 1 priority area for national review by its' field offices. In normal years, $6-$8 Billion goes to local roads programs, but the Stimulus Package will more than double this allocation. Unless effective oversight is put in place, waste, fraud and abuse are inevitable! 
 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/what-do-we-mean-by-transparancy
 
 
 what do we mean by transparancy?
 
 


 When we ask, "What is transparancy?", t 
 he real question is what
level of granularity should be used to track and report allocation
and usage of funds? 
 Does every
 organization that is involved in the process need to identify their
 level of involvement for every amount of funding? Does traceability
 include tracking subcontracted labor? Down to the resource level? Should firms
 receiving funds be required to disclose labor categories [i.e. U.S.
 labor versus foreign, offshore or H-1B/B-1/L-1 labor] Should firms
 receiving funds be required to disclose sourcing of supplies and
 materials? [ Pipe Made in India Incenses Illinois Town , 
 <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/16/business/economy/16pipe.html?partner=MOREOVERNEWS&amp;ei=5040">http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/16/business/economy/16pipe.html?partner=MOREOVERNEWS&amp;ei=5040</a> ] 
 If the answer is, 'yes'
to any of these or similar questions, all funding needs to be tracked
to its lowest level. At what point does the need for transparency
begin to 
 Infringe on
 Corporate Privacy? Negatively impact an
 organizations competitive edge? Divert support to
 required overhead and away from the initial intent/purpose of funds? 
 In addition, should
Recovery.gov be enabled to allow individuals to report abuse of
allocated Recovery Act funds in addition to, or instead of, existing
mechanisms? 
 A clear need raised by
these questions is the need for Federal guidance and policy with
respect to information privacy. Existing federal guidelines and
policy provide limited direction with respect to State and Local
governments. Establishing an overarching guideline for each local
jurisdiction will appropriately distribute responsibility to the
state and local level. 
 
 There is a great deal of
confusion surrounding this term with regards to the Stimulus package
and Recovery.Gov. A consistent and complete definition of this term
must be created and shared before it can be effectively used.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/safety-and-health-concerns-requirements-during-the-fund-distribution
 
 
 Safety and health concerns, requirements during the fund distribution.
 
 Ensure that all recipients of the Recovery funds ensure that all activites when performed are done in a safe and healthy manner. All applicable State, Federal or Local Municipality EHS codes must be adhered to. Any violation can and should result in funds being held or not distributed.
