src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/data-centric-management-principles-for-recovery.org
 
 
 Data-centric Management Principles for Recovery.org
 
 Achieving full
transparency and accountability for Recovery act stimulus funds is a delicate
data driven effort that requires careful deliberate implementation. To accomplish the goals of this initiative--to
collect and present data associated with stimulus funding in order to make it
easy and useful for anyone to track the funds and impact of recovery, all in a
transparent and collaborative fashion--requires the right technology, processes,
and approach to ensure the successful data sharing and collaborative partnership between public and private
sector necessary for national economic recovery. 
 
 Achieving full
transparency and accountability for Recovery act stimulus funds is a delicate
data driven effort that requires careful deliberate implementation. To accomplish the goals of this initiative--to
collect and present data associated with stimulus funding in order to make it
easy and useful for anyone to track the funds and impact of recovery, all in a
transparent and collaborative fashion--requires the right technology, processes,
and approach as part of a collaborative partnership between public and private
sector. 
 
 The following six
data-centric principles establish a foundation of transparency and
collaboration necessary to forge a private/public sector partnership that
achieves the goals of the historic Economic Recovery Act. 
 
 
 
 
 
 The following six
data-centric principles establish the foundation of transparency and
collaboration needed to forge a private/public sector partnership that
achieves the goals of the historic Economic Recovery Act. 
 
 In short, the solution for
recovery.gov requires that Recovery Data be: 
 
 1. Easily Collectible. Given the
breadth of purposes for stimulus funds and the number of government agencies,
partners, vendors, organizations and individuals involved, to ensure successful rapid delivery of a data
management solution, recovery.gov must implement a solution that allows
for the automated collection, reporting, and organization of data from the
widest range sources (e.g., as systems, databases, mainframes, flat files),
interfaces (e.g., web-services, EDI) and
formats (Excel, XML) possible without costly custom coding or integration. Additionally, cloud hosted services could provide
an effective scalable cost competitive approach for handling source data files
coming from hundreds or even thousands of organizations for loading into
persistent storage areas such as Operational Data Stores, Enterprise Data
Warehouses, or Data Marts or staging areas. 
In short, given today's technology, connectivity and handling of data in
various existing data sources and formats should not be an impediment for
organizations providing data to recovery.gov. 
 
 2. High Quality. As learned by
hundreds of companies and organizations over the last decade, accessibility of data
is not enough. Data must be consistent,
complete, and clean (error free) to be useful. 
While practically "perfect data" does not exist, the Recovery
Team can ensure Recovery Data remains meaningful through development of a data
governance program that establishes standards and accountability for
maintaining effective data quality for submitted data, and implementation
supporting automated tools and processes that will help identify and resolve
data quality issues in collaboration with data providers and stakeholders on an
ongoing basis. 
 
 3. Presentation
Agnostic. Integration costs and associated code
maintenance are rapidly becoming one of the most expensive aspects of data
system maintenance. To ensure the
recovery.gov solution remains low maintenance and low cost, the Recovery Team
needs a solution that makes Recovery Data easy to access, analyze and use. Consistent with industry best practices,
data should be separated (e.g. via a data warehouse or data marts) and managed
independent of presentation and application logic. This separation when coupled with standard
integration interfaces should allow Recovery Data to be accessed and used by a
wide range of tools, systems and technologies. 
For example, the solution could support presentation of canned reports
via the recovery.org site, provide standard web search interfaces, integrate
with business intelligence tools for reports and trend analysis, and
interoperate with data mining tools to support robust monitoring by regulators
and law enforcement, to name a few. 
 
 4. Web Accessible /
Mashable. The Recovery Team can provide significant
capabilities at minimal cost by harnessing the power of the private
sector. As proven by recent Internet
developments, Web 2.0 sites have already proven the significant advantages of open
access to data sources. By providing
data feeds that make Recovery information accessible and retrievable by
external web-services, the Recovery team can harness the creative power of the
private sector by allowing developers to create a host of value-added
applications. Just as internet site
zillow.com has created a valuable service by combining existing public records,
Real Estate information, and Microsoft map data, enterprising individuals and
organizations in both the public and private sector will be able to harness
recovery data to create applications that track the usage of government funds
and assess the impact of recovery efforts, thereby providing tremendous value
at minimal cost to the Recovery Team. 
 
 5. Highly Reliable,
Always Available. Few things pose a greater risk to the appearance and
promise of transparency than downtime or other technical issues that prevent
interested parties from consistently and reliably accessing Recovery Data. While superficially, system outages, even for
short periods, may seem innocuous, in the global court of public opinion, such
outages can lead to a perceived lack of openness, or even incompetence. To prevent such misperceptions, and ensure
consistent access to government data, the Recovery Team must provide a highly
available environment proven capable of scaling to provide uninterrupted
support for all of recovery.gov's data collection and dissemination
efforts. Additionally, for web applications
to work, developers creating mashable sites will require similar consistent
always-on real-time access to Recovery Data. 
 
 6. Verifiable and
Auditable. Beyond effective management and accessibility of
data, ensuring that economic recovery funds are appropriately spent requires
that data consumers (such as regulators, the media, and law enforcement) be
able to determine where the data originated, who provided it, and when it was
received. By implementing metadata
management tools that leverage existing metadata from systems submitting data,
the recovery team can simplify data tracking by automating much of this
typically onerous but highly critical regulatory process. 
 
 About Informatica 
 
 Informatica is a leading
provider of enterprise data integration software and services. With Informatica, organizations can gain
greater business value by integrating all their information assets from across
the enterprise. Used by hundreds of successful very large organizations worldwide, Informatica's data integration platform combines industry leading tools with the unmatched ease of use needed to rapidly address the full range of organizations' data integration challenges.

 Open, Accessible, Interoperable Raw Data
 
 Publish as much raw data as possible using open, self-describing, interoperable standards such a RDF [1]. 
 The World Wide Web Consortium has a study group drafting a report on improving access to government through the Web. A draft [2] of this report is available now; the final report is expected before the end of May. 
 [1] http://www.w3.org/RDF/ [2] http://www.w3.org/TR/egov-improving/ 
 
 By publishing raw data, the collective talents and creativity of citizens on the Web will produce more views and analyses than any single entity could conceive -- or fund. The raw data, with explicit links to understand its semantics, will allow independent verification of others' analyses. 
 It is vital that all material be published in forms accessible to all.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/direct-input-of-progress-reports-by-recovery-project-managers
 
 
 Direct Input of Progress Reports by Recovery Project Managers
 
 
 A designated senior manager for each Recovery Project is given an ID and a password. Using these the manager will contribute regular reports to an appropriate web site. 
 Managers must choose a specific timing interval between these reports. The interval might be for example between weekly and quarterly and would depend on the type of work being done and on the length of the project. 
 Each contribution will contain a free text report on the incremental progress and the work done since the previous report. Each report will contain a numeric data summary. The values required for each summary will be entered via a grid that contains a field for each data entity previously agreed for the Recovery Project or for a family of Recovery Projects. N.B. A family may contain every road and bridge Recovery Project in the country for example whilst an individual Recovery Project may be one which stands alone from any other nationally. 
 The fields required for each grid will be selected from those produced by the distillation of ideas currently being collected this week on this web site. Each Recovery Project grid will evidence entities like: Progress; Expenditure; Accountability; Time/ Quality/ Expenditure (key criteria used by project managers). The reporting process needs to keep to a minimum the number of entities needed to maintain public transparency. This proposal is intended only to supplement the existing management systems it does not pretend to replace them. 
 The reporting web site chosen will also produce a RAG Report (Red/ Amber/ Green) for each report submitted to give immediate superficial visibility for each project and for each family project member. 
 Every report will be made available in it's entirety to a public who may access them in a variety of ways e.g. by subject (e.g. green projects); by location (State County); by cost (big/ medium/ small); projects on time; projects in danger of falling behind etc. etc. 
 To give greater transparency and to nurture greater public involvement the public should be allowed to interact individual reports of their choice by submitting questions to the reporting manager or by submitting individual proposals on how individuals might offer a helping hand to overcome local issues or problems raised in the reporting cycle. 
 Reporting managers should be given the discretion to answer the public individually or collectively by using the same reporting media. Where appropriate individual members of the public should be invited to participate and to help the Recovery Project direct.

 Transparency (visibility) 
 Accuracy &amp; Accountability (managers provide the information) 
 RAG Reporting for all projects (traffic lights report progress)

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/open-standards-based-oversight-platform
 
 
 Open, Standards-Based, Oversight Platform 
 
 A holistic approach to Enterprise Risk, Compliance, and Oversight that helps institutions create a single, integrated platform allowing all stakeholders to monitor and report conformance to agency and regulatory policies. The approach focuses on capabilities that implement an enterprise-wide audit and control environment that spans operations, geographies, and business lines. Implementing this platform and tools will help streamline processes and workflow, as well as enable greater collaboration and analysis and reporting across the oversight environment. 
 
 The <a href="http://www.recovery.gov/?q=content/recovery-accountability-and-transparency-board&amp;x=1"> Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board (RATB) </a> is responsible for overseeing all funds under the Recovery Act and providing the public with a direct and immediate link to spending through Recovery.gov. The RATB not only wants to provide the public with unprecedented oversight of Recovery Act funds, but also ensure swift and immediate action to prevent fraud, waste, and mismanagement. 
 
 Recovery.gov is currently working to provide an on-line complaint and hotline service to log suspected fraudulent use of the recovery money. In the meantime, it is recommending the use of the autonomous Offices of Inspector General at the Federal Level to report fraud, waste, or mismanagement of Recovery Act funds. 
 
 Unfortunately these OIG's do not have the ability to share or collaborate - their information technology platforms have been designed around their stated responsibilities. Generally, each organization collects its own data and maintains its own technology platforms necessary to perform their oversight function. 
 
 Until these issues are addressed, information technology will inhibit rather than support a modern, unified and collaborative oversight and regulatory environment. 
 
 As Recovery.gov looks to improve this process, it should ensure the most current data is made available from a single, viable source to ensure compliance. Microsoft offers software and solutions that quickly integrate disparate 'silos' and unlock value by connecting systems that drive new operational efficiencies, increase transparency and accelerate innovation across the enterprise. 
 
 An example of where existing investments can be leveraged to provide a more effective view of the data is Microsoft's <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/industry/government/solutions/Single_View_Platform/default.aspx" target="_blank"> Single View Platform </a>. This solution leverages capabilities that agencies already possess coupled with public service mapping capabilities to deliver a geographic view of complex information and data sets across multiple roles and location. The Single View Platform provides: 
 
 
 Comprehensible visual presentation of data. 
 
 Access to real-time or near real-time information. 
 
 Integration of multiple information sets from disparate sources. 
 
 Sharing information inside and outside the agency, with restricted access controls. 
 
 Powerful Business Intelligence and Analytics capabilities. 
 
 Portfolio Management, Task Management and Tracking engines. 
 
 Interoperability with existing and legacy systems. 
 
 A Single View Platform solution can be deployed using the existing agency investments coupled with public data services to provide transparency and accountability quickly and at low cost.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/how-to-improve-the-value-of-recovery-gov-data
 
 
 How to Improve the Value of Recovery.gov Data
 
 The Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board should work with the Federal Chief Financial Officer's (CFO) Council and industry to develop guidance for agencies in securing Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) financial management platforms to manage the financial data submitted to Recovery.gov. This guidance should encourage agencies to purchase Information Technology (IT) solutions that easily integrate with existing systems, and enable agencies to view financial data at the macro- and micro-levels (e.g., project code, organization, by vendor, etc.). In addition, this guidance should recommend that these solutions are scalable and facilitate agency use of financial management data for improved performance management, project management, and capital planning. 
 
 Providing transparency and accountability into the use of American Reinvestment and Recovery Act (ARRA) funds is essential. Just as important, however, is making sure that agencies reap the benefits of this data to improve planning and financial management. Without the capability to view and analyze this data, reporting to Recovery.gov runs the risk of becoming simply another government data call. Unfortunately, many agencies rely on a complex system of Excel spreadsheets and/or homegrown IT systems to manage their financial data. The result is that these agencies are unable to fully analyze ARRA - and other agency data - over the long-term to make better business decisions that link program, organization, and agency investments with performance metrics and mission success. With guidance from the Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board, the CFO Council, and industry, agencies will see purchasing financial management IT solutions as an Administration priority and act on it, ultimately improving the value of Recovery.gov data and the effectiveness of government. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/reporting-should-be-reliable-timely-complete-and-ensure-reconciliation
 
 
 Reporting should be reliable, timely, complete and ensure reconciliation 
 
 The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) requirements are linked to Federal Financial Accountability and Transparency Act (FFATA) by Sec. 1526[c] 7 and EESA/TARP by Sec. 114. Therefore, all reporting requirements of FFATA apply to ARRA. One exception is that the $25,000 threshold does not apply to ARRA reporting. All Federal expenditures should be accounted for to the last penny as required by the ARRA. 
 · Reconciliation needs to be accomplished between the following reporting systems: 
 
 a. State Recovery.gov websites 
 b. Federal Recovery.gov Agency website 
 c. Federal Recovery.gov Board website 
 d. Office of Management and Budget Reporting 
 e. Department of Treasury, Financial Management Service Government-wide Accounting (GWA) system and their related: 
 · Daily and Monthly Treasury Statements 
 · Combined Statement of Receipts, Outlays, and Balances, and 
 · Financial Report of the United States Government. 
 The collection of data using spreadsheets will not accomplish this objective . 
 · Expenditure Reporting for Prime and sub-tier reporting for contracts, grants, and loans must be accounted for to the "nth tier", per FFATA requirements. The "first tier only" requirement of Recovery.gov ARRA requirements does not meet the FFATA requirement of "nth tier" reporting. 
 · Accounting control of data is critical. The source of data should originate from Federal agencies and contractor, grantee, and loan lenders' audited accounting systems, not from spreadsheets or miscellaneous unreliable formats in order to insure accuracy and reduce or eliminate reconciliation problems. 
 · Any system should provide for analysis of the performance of grants, contracts, and loans not just expenditure reporting. 
 
 Transparent reporting needs to be reliable, timely, and accessible to all to insure trust and accountability. 
 
 
 
 These measures are required to conform to the all transparency and accountability legislation. Reconciliation is a key element to ensure accurate, reliable data for decision making. 
 
 Performance management is necessary because just knowing how much money was spent on a project or initiative is not as meaningful as determining whether the project or initiative was over or under budget, and how it met expected timelines, and achieved projected results.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/earned-value-management-for-infrastructure-projects
 
 
 Earned Value Management for Infrastructure Projects
 
 Require Earned Value Management for Major Infrastructure Projects. 
 
 
 With $150 Billion to be spent on new infrastructure, it is important that these projects be managed well. Earned Value Management provides a proven way to track not just how much has been spent on a project, but how much "value" has been "earned" based on original cost estimates. By the time as little as 15-20% of the project has been completed, the estimated cost at completion can be estimated with a high degree of accuracy. This gives time to either correct poorly managed efforts or cancel them before significant funds have been wasted. This is not "new science", and there are many knowledgeable practitioners. Demonstrated skill in this discipline is required to achieve Project Management Professional (PMP) and PRINCE2 certifications. However As DoD has recently discovered, without strong oversight of the requirement, Earned Value implementations will not be robust. The Office of the Secretary of Defense has recently issued more stringent guidance to correct this problem. This should be carried over to the major capital projects under the Recover Act. It's like telling someone how to lose weight (eat less, do more), but without discipline, they tend to fall short of expectations.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/utilize-nist-to-define-core-data-elements-that-will-allow-for-transparency
 
 
 Utilize NIST to define core data elements that will allow for transparency
 
 One idea is to have the National Institute of Standards and Technology to define specific data elements that would be required for agency level data to improve transparency. This would standardize / normalize the data sets across the entire government. These would be the starting blue prints for every program that would be easily auditable as well as added to as programs evolve. Then NIST would have an update process to have these additions to be added to their national standard. 
 
 Let me first put my point of view in to perspective. I am a entrepreneur that has owned quite a few companies and is looking at this open forum as a way to discuss ideas and best practices with no preconceived notions or solutions to sell. I am fully vested in this country and would like to see it perform as well as any company can.

While this may seem like a foreign topic, it is not as foreign as we may think. In fact, I believe the issue comes down to the same fundamental question that is being asked at Recovery.org. 
 How do we improve government so there is transparency and accountability throughout all government and the government contractors? 
 Private businesses have struggled with transparency and accountability as they have grown for many years but their ability to be more agile than the public sector has been expedited as their ownership has been held to a limited number of key stakeholders. This has allowed for the smaller issues to be addressed as they are found in organizations. 
 Businesses have built large data sets but by standardizing and normalizing their data in certain keys the ability to transfer and analyze this data has helped out tremendously. This is essentially what the White House has asked for NIST to do for the health care industry. So, in short, it would be a common sense opportunity unless it takes too much time to get these standards developed.

 This takes Recovery.gov to a new level of transparency for the public. It not only shows from the federal angle where funds are going, but searching other governmental agency recovery sites brings it all together in one place, making it easier for the citizen to focus in on what's of interest to them. 
 When the information is aggregated in the search index created in this manner, then it can be subcategorized or clustered in ways that make it easier for the public to dive into the data.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/alfresco-for-web-site-tableau-for-visualization-cmis-for-data-sharing
 
 
 Alfresco for Web Site; Tableau for visualization; CMIS for data sharing; 
 
 Web Site CMS + Virtualized computing clouds Use the open source enterprise-grade content management system Alfresco for the Web site. Run it on virtual machines on private computing clouds (VMware vSphere 4) for maximum scalability. Couple that with Amazon computing cloud clusters to handle load spikes. 
 Tableau for data Visualization, Exploration &amp; Dashboards Use Tableau (server-based version) for the visualization of data. Work with Tableau and data visualization experts such as Edward Tufte to create analysis packagages for data visualization that can easily be manipulated by Joe data or experts. Deliver the raw data, but also deliver the tools to extend the utility of the data to a wider audience. Tableau provides tools to not only visualize data, but to explore the data. 
 Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS) CMIS or Content Management Interoperability Services, was proposed as a
draft standard in September 2008 and submitted to OASIS. Proposed by
the largest ECM vendors (IBM, EMC, Microsoft) It is based on REST and SOAP bindings for content exchange
between content repositories regardless of the ECM platform. This would
make it simple for multiple agencies to publish content on their own
sites and have it automatically be aggregated on a
single web presence. 
 Alfresco is CMIS-capable Alfresco supports CMIS. Given that it is open source, a content-delivery package could be created to be installed locally (or run on cloud services) by any agency. This would cut out redundant work to create infrastructure by each agency. 
 Alfresco supports ATOM, XForms, and has a light-weight scripting framework (SURF). The scripting framework can talk to the repository back-end; making it simple to create packaged web-applications that can be distributed quickly. In addition,being able to talk to repositories using CMIS would simplify the data integration problem. 
 Alfresco is extensible ; open source Engage the developer community to create a solution around an established enterprise-grade solution. 
 Alfresco supports JBoss jBPM for packaged business processes Utilize jBoss jBPM that Alfresco uses for designing pre-packaged processes that support waste, fraud, and abuse detection. 
 
 It combines open source and best-in-class resources to deliver a solution quickly.

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/beyond-the-information-strategic-and-tactical-governance
 
 
 Beyond the Information: Strategic and Tactical Governance
 
 Include a strategic and tactical management/governance system on top of/in conjunction with data collection middleware/metadata models so that real decisions can be made based on the underlying information. 
 
 Per the e-mail sent addressing potential data models and metadata/middle ware tools: Collecting all of the information in the world does not lead to proactive accountability unless you are actively able to make decisions based on the information. Unless there is a real threat of losing funds to a more worthy recipient (worthiness, in this case, can be based on efficiency or effectiveness metrics), there is little incentive to improve the processes by which funds are consumed. By implementing a strategic and tactical management layer fed by data from the collection mechanisms discussed here, you can answer questions such as: 
 1) What are the most efficient uses of funds? Which recipients create the most jobs OR serve the most patients OR construct the most miles of road, etc.? 
 2) What would be the overall impact of switching funds from one recipient (or set of recipients) to another? (A what-if scenario capability.) 
 3) What steps need be taken in order to effectively do a switch and insure that it happens quickly and efficiently? (Tactical governance such as notifications, etc.) 
 Only by leveraging all of the collected data to make future decisions based on performance will ultimately lead to a culture of accountability and the end result that all of us want from the transparency involved. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/technology-solution-optimization
 
 
 Technology/Solution Optimization
 
 
 Technology/Solution Optimization 
 Consider building a solution that really adds value for your partners. That has the potential to be internalized into their business processes in meaningful ways not just something that satisfies your basic requirements. 
 Build to a non proprietary extensible service based framework - SOA 
 Incorporate open standards with maximum acceptance and the strongest tool support 
 Build common enabling services to minimize cost, simplify buy in and align with business functions 
 Reuse as much proven technology as possible 
 Error on the side of simplicity and transparency 
 Agility, flexibility, and interoperability should drive the design 
 Adopt new technologies/standards prudently to evolve the model. 
 Standardize information exchange metadata 
 Consider all sophistication levels for access to the data 
 Reduce burden and costs for submitters and users 
 Promote interoperability through the use of open standards 
 Build an architecture not tools

 
 These concepts represent 8 years of practical design and implementation lessons learned from a nationwide system implementation that closely paralells this effort. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/grow-a-development-data-analysis-community
 
 
 Grow a Development &amp; Data Analysis Community
 
 Recovery.gov has a chance to be a model of data access for the entire US Government. What follows is to build not just tools and reports but a community of developers on top of that data. This community can collaboratively develop free software tools - tailor-made for this data - that can evolve as the data sources get richer. (see Ubuntu.com for a thriving example community) 
 
 The tools to build this community exist already in software projects like Trac, MediaWiki, and Git. The developers can use their tools of choice but programming languages such as PHP, Python, and Perl, as well as databases like MySQL and PostgreSQL would naturally play a large part in building this community. 
 
 If this effort is to benefit the people of the United States optimally, it should attract the best and brightest globally in terms of developers. The tools mentioned above are what those developers want to use. 
 
 Another goal should be to keep costs to the public as low as possible. Under this community-building model, companies will sprout up and fund themselves to provide extra polish, support, and analysis over and above what the community builds. 
 
 Sincerely, 
 
 David Sterry 
 TryGNULinux.com

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/fraud-awareness-training-for-federal-employees
 
 
 Fraud Awareness training for federal employees
 
 Federal employees are the "eyes and ears" of their respective programs, grants, and contracts. While almost everyone knows what constitutes "lying, cheating, and stealing" there is a lot of uncertainty of what to do about suspected fraud, partly because there is no current training in fraud awareness. Fraud awareness training is not universally mandated and many contracting officers, COTR's and others are not required to file financial disclosure forms. Institute annual fraud awareness training through the website Recovery.Gov so feds have a better idea of what to report, how to report it, and confidence that their reports won't be "Madoffed" away. 
 
 This training/outreach will improve both the quality and quantity of data and tips coming from the "front lines" of where ARRA funds are being spent. 
 

src: http://www.thenationaldialogue.org/ideas/secure-coding-training-for-developers
 
 
 Secure Coding Training for Developers
 
 The data government houses and has to protect is often times sensitive in nature. Developers in the workforce today often have not had training in writing secure code. Higher education institutions have yet to implement security into their curriculum. Training for both those entering the public sector workforce and those already in it is a must. 
 
 Government budgets are tight and yet more and more public services are being offered online. Online services are a wonderful advantage for the constituents, although it puts their personal data at risk. As hackers get more sophisticated, so must the methods of protection. The only way to accomplish this is to build security into the development process of our applications.
